Aaron Sorkin adapted his play "A Few Good Men" from the stage to screen in 1992 and has been working steadily in Hollywood ever since. Because of this I normally assume he's probably written somewhere between 10-15 screenplays and was shocked to learn that as of now he has only written seven. It just feels like every two years we hear about a new Sorkin screenplay, so much so that most people use him as the film's selling point over the director. It's incredible to see a writer with such a distinct style that his work is able to supersede the directing stylings of David Fincher, Danny Boyle and Bennett Miller.Danny Boyle directs "Steve Jobs" at an electrifying pace. He's able to turn Sorkin's dialogue to nearly explosive levels. Boyle always seems to be on the fringe of being an A-list director but just isn't quite there, despite a "Best Director" award from the Academy in 2008. His name just doesn't quite carry the same cachet that others do; very few people say "well the trailer doesn't look great but I'm not worried because it's Danny Boyle," like they might do for say Spielberg or the Coen Brothers. Still, you have to give him credit for making an inherently boring subject matter very lively in "Steve Jobs."The movie could have very easily devolved into flashy shouting matches between titanic actors practically looking at the camera and flat-out asking for Oscar nominations but it never happens. Michael Fassbender is definitely flashy but he never goes out of control with the role of Jobs the way an actor like DiCaprio would. He's very convincing despite bearing absolutely no resemblance to the real-life king of Apple. He walks a great tight wire between charming and unpleasant, riding on mostly his own self-assurance that he is a genius, even though everyone in his inner circle constantly tries to get him to "manage expectations" about both his stature and his products' success.The supporting cast is just as good as Fassbender and we always want to see more of them. Jeff Daniels and Fassbender share an incredibly riveting exchange during the climax of the second act that keeps you locked in on the screen. The movies flashes back and forth between the past and present, giving us the perfect context necessary right before we need it; it's a bold move and thankfully it pays off well. Kate Winslet plays a great right-hand man to Fassbender's Jobs and get to share the screen with him more than anyone else and seems to be the only character capable of navigating the wayward wiring of Jobs' thoughts, with a performance that always seem rightfully stressed-out without ever asking the audience for the slightest pity.Seth Rogen acts as the emotional and moral high ground of the film as Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak. Rogen makes the smart choice not to try too hard at "serious acting." He does what he has always been good at, playing an affable man who knows when to get serious. I'm not surprised that Rogen gave a great performance in a serious movie. Not at all. "Knocked Up" has serious moments that play out just the way they should, the only difference is the larger context of most of his movies are on the goofier side but he is still a great actor no matter the context of the movie, which is why I groan when people get head-over-heels that someone from the comedy world was able to hold their own in a drama. Rogen is such a treat to watch and is able to play funny and immediately flip to aggressive in one beat. He perfectly encapsulates that sick feeling you get when you can tell one of your friends thinks their better than you. He's the character we relate to the most; if you find yourself relating more to Steve Jobs then you're probably either an asshole or think you're better than you actually are.This movie fits into a strange place in the current film landscape. Yes it is entertaining from start to finish and I've actually found myself thinking about it now and again almost a week after seeing it, but I have my doubts about whether or not people will still be talking about this five years from now, let alone even one. The film ends long before the iPhone debuts which is a smart move, as to avoid becoming merely and "movie of the moment." There is a slight nod to the iPod near the end of the film, but not in a way that really ages it in any capacity. So what we're left with is a peculiar picture that is half biopic, half historical fiction. It fits in better with "American Hustle" than it does with biopics like "Walk the Line" or even the original "Jobs" film.

This is far from my favorite Sorkin screenplay, but a very good one nonetheless. Boyle's direction and choice of using 16mm, 35mm and digital film for the 3 different time periods is great. Fassbender, Winslet, Rogen and Daniels all put on great performances as well. This film only came up short for me because I was expecting something as great as "The Social Network," and this obviously came up short of that, but it is still a great film.
VERY WORDY - AND WORTHY.

A film with very, very unfortunate destiny. It reminded me of "Carnage", another very solid film with Kate Winslet, but flopped miserably in the box office. "Steve Jobs" is a fascinating film with powerful characters, subtle dialogue that reveals just enough for the audience to grab its meaning but requires them way more time to understand its subtext. The first "act" is kind-of slow, but the rest is simply exploding, especially the last confrontation between Jobs and his daughter (played by no other than the daughter of "Kill Bill"'s The Bride, who has grown up beautifully!). A very well-done film that deserves way more attention.

Steve Jobs is a sleek film, using a narrative structure that is unique and cool. The only criticism I have of the film is that it can at times feel heartless, though one could argue that it is intentional. I wish more people would see this as it really is worth the time if for no other reason then the performance of Michael Fassbender.
Movie was great. True story and true emotion was felt from the beginning to the end. I like michael fassbender acting. IO give 4-5 stars to this movie.
If you like dialogue driven movies then you will love this.
Fascinating film from start to finish. Great writing, awesome cast, terrific approach of the narrative structure. Phenomenal in every ways.

Nowadays, it seems there's a new Steve Jobs movie every day. The latest, Steve Jobs, is the best of them all, if only because we see the late Apple CEO cast in a new light. Michael Fassbender's work as the titular character is splendid, as we gain a greater sense of the personal life behind the technological icon.
I you enjoy watching a two hour long argument then you will enjoy this film. Otherwise save your money and don't go to see this really quite poor film
Um filme que podia ser uma excepcional pe�a de teatro.

A very interesting take on the Steve Jobs story. Michael Fassbender deliver a very convincing performance that would sure to see a lot of awards attention this fall. The supporting cast that consist of Kate Winslet, Seth Rogen, and Jeff Daniels are also very solid here. Danny Boyle signature style is not very apparent here but he did put together a great film. But the true star here of course is Aaron Sorkin and his script.

Powerful performances from its leading actors, followed by an outstanding script and completing itself with an astonishing directing, Steve Jobs does the job of deliviring the origin story of the Apple founder with the atmosphere of older times with a cinematic touch.

The dialogue, penned by Aaron Sorkin, is great but the nature of the piece (a biopic compressed into three acts centered around three pivotal product launches in Steve Jobs' career) stifles proper character development because the audience only gets a taste of the players and their relationships. Furthermore it is preposterous to think they would only speak to one another right before important presentations and never speak to each other outside said events. As stated by others on this site, this script would've made a great play but it makes a OK movie. Michael Fassbender is trying is best to recreate Steve Jobs but he comes up short. Seth Rogen is miscast as Steve Wozniak. Kate Winslet is good as the fictional composite character. The rest of the cast is alright.The interplay between characters is lively and captivating at first but the all too familiar walk-and-talk rhythm by Aaron Sorkin (not to mention the self-righteousness of the characters in his scripts) gets old by the halfway point. To me, the film seems to peak too early when Jobs and John Scully (played by Jeff Daniels) duke it out in the second act over the circumstances surrounding Jobs' ouster as Apple CEO, and from there on the intensity just seeps out of the movie. Predictably, the filmmakers couldn't resist themselves by adding a good amount of overwrought sentimentality surrounding the character of Lisa Brennan-Jobs.I suppose the subject of Steve Jobs is just too tricky a subject to bring to life on the big screen via a major motion picture with a cast of well-known Hollywood actors. He is however wonderful cannon fodder for biographies and documentaries.

Steve Jobs is a perpetually absorbing, wonderfully innovative, and deeply human film that is more of a three-act character study than a biopic - and it is all the better for it. Sorkin's script is undoubtedly the best of the year (maybe the decade), Fassbender's performance is completely deserving of any and every award in existence, and the soundtrack from little-known composer Daniel Pemberton is astonishing. Steve Jobs is a film that will stick with you long after it cuts to black. You will sit in silence and contemplate what you just witnessed, because you're sure that it was a historical innovation in film and unlike anything you've ever seen before. Easily one of the best of the year.

Serves as a good insight into the man behind it all, but it doesn't really tell us much about the man himself. It is mostly a behind the scenes real time reenactment behind three of his biggest product launches spread over a 14 year period (think 30-40 minutes per segment (with a few mountage sequences to bridge the gaps and a few flashbacks)). I did find it interesting to watch though and it is a pretty good film but it is hard to find there to be much to it.
"Steve Jobs" is in itself a significant complex, but at the same time a completely honest look at the entrepreneur who changed technology forever.

Dizzying with its dialogue, Steve Jobs tells the story of its titular man through three Apple product launches, 1985's Macintosh computer, 1988's Apple rival and failure, Next, and 1998's iMac, the beginning of the re-emergence of Apple into ubiquity. It's really an Aaron Sorkin movie above all else, which means we get absurdly intelligent characters walking and talking at rapid-fire with brilliant one-liners and snappy dialogue that bristles with musicality to it, the kind that your ears perk up for. It's a feast for the ears; however, Steve Jobs is really an emotionally cold stage play on film. Danny Boyle (Slumdog Millionaire) is the director but the staginess of the conceit is too much for the visually nimble filmmaker to overcome. There are a few small visual flourishes as inserts but the star is Sorkin's verbose screenplay. We get a glimpse into the prickly, egotistical, bullying, visionary, and curious man that was Steve Jobs. His continual denial of being the father to his daughter is a source of great contrarian insight. The structure of the script lends itself to repetition and artificiality. All these characters keep turning up and having these important conversations at these moments? After a while it feels like the characters are talking in circles and waiting for catharsis, and the concluding ten minutes is a detour into unearned sentiment. The movie and its major themes just do not come together with the clarity or force that the filmmakers believe. Michael Fassbender is superb as Jobs and there isn't a bad performance in the bunch. It's an engaging movie in the moment but I don't feel like I know Jobs any better than before. In attempting to tell the life of one influential man, Sorkin has made the movie about himself, but The Social Network this is not. Nate's Grade: B

First off, this movie is leagues beyond the 2013 version, which I didn't hate. The structure and directing are quite impressive. One aspect of Boyle's work that is lacking is trimming the fat of Sorkin's script. Sorkin is an extremely gifted writer but he needs a director to control him. Fincher did that perfectly in "The Social Network", but here Boyle seems to just let so many scenes go on and on. The movie is mentally exhausting at times. Still, the subplot with Job's daugther is perfect and adds emotional weight to the coldness of the film and all three actresses who portray his daughter, Lisa, do a fine damn good job, as does the rest of the cast.

Not sure how those who haven't read the book can make much sense of this which is probably why it's performing so badly in cinemas. A very intelligent film with a great script/performances, the unusual editing style means the film often feels like a two hour trailer but it's a clever way of capturing Job's perspective: paradoxically erratic and elegant and completely non-linear. The cliche of his journey towards empathy is the only let-down, but it is minor enough to only be a small distraction. The deconstruction of real facts and events into fictional conversations makes this an interesting take on the biopic genre, it doesn't cling slavishly to verisimilitude but it doesn't feed reality into a Hollywood mold either, it takes the truth and remixes it through the film medium to create a virtual docu-drama that is both fictional and true. Very refreshing. 9/10

I've heard so much negativity around Steve Jobs the man and this film shows alot of that (despite what Apple and Jobs fanboys claim) but there is a hint of a good person underneath all that. On the other hand though this movie shows the marketing genius that he was and its no wonder why Apple are so popular now. Michael Fassbender was awesome as Jobs and was supported brilliantly by the stellar cast and obviously the Aaron Sorkin penned script and the directional prowess of Danny Boyle made this such a riviting watch
Overall, Steve Jobs is a well acted, finely directed drama, and has a well written script, but doesn't captivate or entertain as much as one would hope.
A hagiography for the sophisticated consumer. Or something less pretentious sounding than that, but meaning exactly the same thing.

Sorkin, Fassbender, Winslet and Boyle at their finest in this verbose, dynamic, intense set of three snapshots into Jobs' monomaniacal mind. A very touching father-daughter thread weaves the three together. No iPhone though!

It's hard to not equate this film to "The Social Network," since both stories are told by the same screenwriter. However, that's not necessarily a bad thing. No, it doesn't have the same "wow" factor as its equally technical and complex 2010 predecessor, but both main characters are equally dynamic, innovative, and, often times, dislikable - which is a testament to how well both characters are played. Unlike the previous "Jobs" film, this iteration doesn't hold back in portraying the more difficult sides of the former Apple CEO. Yet somehow, it seems to paint a much more authentic picture of who he really was.
When I was a kid- apple, blackberry and orange were fruits!!Doesn't paint Mr. Jobs in a good light - a bit of an iC**t

Despite being reigned in to a small subset of incidents in the Apple co founder's life this picture's feel of scale far outstrips the Kutcher lead film. The score and use of newsreel footage works well. The story of Jobs though, seen through either his business or personal life does seem a waste of the talents involved in a collaboration of Sorkin, Boyle and Fassbender.

Really gripping and entertaining film. If you really enjoyed "Social Network," then you should really enjoy this film as well. I don't particularly like Aaron Sorkin as a person, but he writes dynamite screenplays, that will bend the truth as necessary to create a compelling narrative.Bear in mind, this is *not* a traditional biopic -- instead it ties together a series of vignettes in Jobs' life. Nothing in the film actually takes place past 1998.

Great acting but shame they decided to focus the movie around three product launches. For me I would have liked a more standard biographical story rather than concentrate on the drama of the launches.

In the beginning of time, humans been expose to the greatest inventions: the wheel, automobile, celluloid, ink and computer, there is always one person name as the inventor, but the people behind it were never included as the creators or responsible. Perhaps the miss conceptions of true genius lays in the fact that the creator not necessary is the one who have the skills to do it, is the vision to create it, what is recognize by the society.In the film "Steve Jobs", director Danny Boyle ( Slummdog Millionaire, Trainspotting) presents a very egocentric and arrogant leader of the Apple corporation in 3 major landmarks of his career. The film build as a 3 acts introduce the major characters, develop around the keynotes when a new product is been introduce, but also set the foundation of Steve Jobs persona.The first act begins with the challenges for Apple presenting the Macintosh computer in 1983. We see a young Steve Jobs (Michael Fasbender) full of arrogance, treating his engineers as puppets forcing them to work as hard as a can to make the computer smile. While all this is happening his marketing executive Joanna Hoffman (Kate Winslet) is dealing the paternity dispute revealed in a Time Magazine, who brought Chrisann Brennan (Katherine Waterson) to the theater where the keynote is taking place so Steve can meet his allegedly daughter Lisa. Danny Boyle presents this 3 long scenes with a outstanding film style showing the stages of every character. Jobs personalities develops with the success of Apple Macintosh, the failure of NeXT and the comeback with iMac. Michael Fasbender is fascinating as Steve Jobs, you care for him for trying to be the father figure, but you also hate him, despise him for the person person that he was, with his colleagues, partners and his workers. But you also admire him for be the center of attention, the visionary who make Apple what it is, a true groundbreaking company that develops good looking products. Ket Winslet is powerful as Joanna Hoffman, she is the voice of conscience for Steve Jobs. But the person who steal the scenes every time it appears is Seth Rogen as Steve Wozniak. Besides of been a pain in the but to Jobs, he is also who is just fighting for the people who build, the Macintosh, the iMac, and other products who make Jobs the star of Apple.Steve Jobs is a powerful film, that is considered more a failure than a success for Hollywood, but is a great example of how to make a biopic, without telling the whole story all over again.
Already a contender for the the Oscar. Must see.

Maybe my fellow bloggers' less than stellar reviews have managed my expectations or maybe I'm just more used to Aaron Sorkin's wordy style after years of watching his work on TV and in films, but I respectfully have to disagree with the other reviews here: the 2hrs running time flew by for me and I really enjoyed the film's original and entertaining take on the biopic genre. I would concede that the structure of the film, using imagined confrontations and meetings with the same set of characters before 3 different product launches; essentially a series of duologues, are too neat and too articulate to be real. But it is a clever conceit that's brilliantly written and executed, summing up the man's achievements while nailing both his ambitiousness as a businessman and his flaws as a human being. Michael Fassbender is mesmerizing but the others, even Seth Rogen, are all given ample screen time to spar with Fassbender and to shine. Between the rhythmic, tension-building editing and Danny Boyle's fluid yet controlled directing, the film manages to make even the dullest corporate dealings as exciting and riveting to watch as any action sequence in your blockbuster thrillers.

A wonderful movie driven by a fascinating character, beautiful cinematography and great performances both by Michael Fassbender and his supporting cast.My only criticism would be regarding the way the movie attempts to squeeze all the major parts of his life into 3 specific 40 minute real time periods. It is an interesting storytelling device but for anyone familiar with the details of Jobs' story it is frustratingly unrealistic and simplistic. Furthermore, the movie paints Jobs' journey as a slow climb to the top whereas it was much more of a rollercoaster.

A biopic that rings hollow and phony from start to finish. Yes, we're well aware of the title character's shady reputation from news reports and other films, but this stagey, pretentious, poorly written and at times needlessly cryptic account of his life becomes truly laughable and tiresome. Michael Fassbender's overwrought, constantly mugging for the camera performance screams "I dare you not to nominate me for an Oscar for this portrayal" (sheesh). Were it not for the solid supporting performances of Kate Winslet and Jeff Daniels, there would be nothing to recommend here. It's now easy to see why the early reviews weren't so kind to this release; it doesn't deserve the praise it has received since.

Focuses on one facet of a very complex person, and in a contrived way (15 minutes before three product launches). Far more fiction than fact, it is at times entertaining -- but don't expect accuracy in either the portrait or history.

A high performance machine sporting an operating system that's at times brilliant but at times slow, Steve Jobs proves a remarkable upgrade from its glitch-filled predecessor and boasts some award worthy hardware besides. Not that the software comes completely riddled with bugs, mind you. The three-act design - set backstage at iconic product launches and ending in 1998 with the unveiling of the iMac - proves to be the greatest and most irksome portion of the film. Rather than present the man in a cradle-to-grave slide show, the film integrates a lot of facts, figures, and (emotional) core processing into three key moments that capture the human factor behind this genius like lightning in a bottle and doesn't completely feel like data processing. Like any multiple storied production, however, some chapters emerge stronger than others and Steve Jobs suffers the slight indignity of the weakest link playing out last. Aaron Sorkin punctuates the goings-on with some super-intelligent zingers (indeed, he has given filmgoers one of the most quotable films of the last decade) and heartfelt back-and-forths (despicable at times, his interactions with his assistant, daughter, and former partner make this a phenomenal performance piece for all involved), but his third act becomes a bit dull before hitting audiences with an engrossing and deeply vetting curtain closer.An R-rated drama based on Walter Isaacson's best-selling biography, this bio-pic takes us behind the scenes of the digital revolution to paint a portrait of the man (Fassbender) at its epicenter. Michael Fassbender flirted with Supporting Actor Oscar before for 12 Years a Slave, but Steve Jobs posits a good reason why he didn't get it: He's a lead performer and deserves Best Actor accolades all the more for this, his best turn yet. Director Danny Boyle deserves a good deal of the credit, however. Despite limited locations, the action always feels fluid and the arena grand. Of course, it helps that the settings compliment Sorkin's walk-and-talk style, pioneered on NBC's The West Wing and put to excellent use here too. Bottom line: Big Mac
A clever premise makes for an engaging, although at times repetitive biopic.

Brilliance. Multiple levels of interest, gripping and thought-provoking. Camera, lighting, scripting and acting all excellent. Danny Boyle exceeds his already-excellent repertoire. Some stuff had to be left out, of course... too many of the significant also-rans are alive and wealthy. So compromises are palpable. But that in itself is a significant achievement ,like getting shades of grey past a black&white censorial lens. Steve Jobs (the film) uses colour, and the lack of it, pace (fast, slow, timestop, flashback), sensitivity, anger, stupidity and brilliance. Imperfection in this movie just illustrates the flaws in its subject. And that is the point.... how to be brilliant, despite your flaws. Danny and Steve, both.

This movie was awful. I read the book and was hoping for something to match the scope of it, but almost the entire movie takes place backstage prior to an Apple announcement. Movie basically only covers his screw up with the LISA computer and his poor relationship with his daughter.
This movie was amazing! Micheal Fassbender, amazing. Kate Winslet, amazing. Seth Rogen, amazing. Jeff Daniels, amazing. Everything else in this movie, amazing!

89%Smartly written, artistically directed, and with Michael Fassbender and Seth Rogan delivering finely wrought performances, Steve Jobs is an engrossing character study, leaving its audience captivated as well as educated.VARITABLE: 79%
My grandma can knit, but not like Sorkin. Boyle oh boyle, this film is well-woven, not a soft wear, mind you - a digitally organic story with lots of hard drive.

Dramatic and fascinating recreation (with a little artistic license) of key periods in Job's life in and out of Apple. Fassbender is excellent and we are left with an impression of Jobs as both interesting as an individual and desperately unpleasant with others.

A movie is as good as its script, Aaron Sorkin gives us the Steve Jobs movie we deserve. Not to take away anything from Danny Boyle or the stars of the movie, but the script was the reason (Jobs) failed miserably. Otherwise, Fassbender, Winslet and surprisingly even Rogan were fantastic.
An interesting portrayal of a complex individual.
Theatric and trought-provoking.

An intelligent, well-acted character study that avoids being another full-life biopic about Steve Jobs and does instead a remarkable job to flesh out his personality through three public events in his life and a few flashbacks - which, in turn, suffer a bit from a rather clumsy editing.

Intense, powerful & truly memorable with super performances by Fassbender, Winslet, Rogen & Daniels. Director Boyle gets absolutely the best out of each actor & tells the story of an adamant genius of our time. A very strong screenplay that is worth watching!
Sorkin just doesn't disappoint, the worry was that some of the other might... thankfully everyone delivered and Fassbender continues to impress.
An incredibly well acted and scripted film that portrays the complex natures of it's main characters elegantly.

Powerful and thrilling, all through intelligent dialogue and impeccable acting and direction. It's a shame the studio pulled it out of so many theaters. I predict it will do well on DVD as word of mouth spreads. At least I hope so. I found it very moving.

I went into this movie expecting to like it. I'm an Apple fan and I've been into technology since I was a kid. So a film about Steve Jobs should've been a hit.How wrong could I be. The entire movie is centered on three launch days. On these three days, events that took place over years magically happen on the same day. I realize that it's a movie and not meant to be history, but this technique has the effect of turning each launch day into a laborious, overwrought string of dramatic yelling and overacting. It was honestly hard to stand - I just wanted the thing to end.I have no idea how accurate it is, if at all. Its one saving grace is the acting done by the three girls who played Lisa - they all looked like the same girl at different ages, and were all great. As for Steve Jobs himself, he comes off as so intolerable I can't imagine anyone dealing with him. If that's how he was in real life, then this movie is in a sense exactly what it should have been - painful to watch.
Best part is the performance of Fassbender. Worst part is the repetition of the setting and characters. I could be genius but it is not. But it is still the best jobs movie until now.

Strong performances highlight this dramatized look into three major events during Steve Jobs' career: the release of the Macintosh, the failed attempt at NeXT, and Jobs eventual return to Apple with the release of the iMac.The film comes out like a play, featuring a small amount of characters and locations throughout, and going through three acts. Fassbender is impressive in portraying Jobs as over-confident and intimidating, expecting nothing but the best with zero excuses.
Poorly executed. Michael Fassbender is compelling.

The structure just makes it feel like you are basically rewatching the same scenes. Can't help but think this would work better in the theatre. Fassbender is good though and will probably get some awards buzz for his performance.

If you read the biography about Steve Jobs by Walter Isaacson I'd suggest: don't watch that movie. While I was watching it, I wanted to leave because the actor was not representing Steve Jobs very well, they did not mention anything about his other kids or his other wife or his disease. Furthermore, it is sad to make such a bad and imperfect movie about a man who lived for perfectionism and change. Don't watch that movie, really.
Boring. Film was far too long.
This movie was much to do about nothing and I can see why it made so little at the box office. If I hadn't got these tickets for free I would have never gone to see it, who needs 3 Steve Jobs movie?
Rather excruciating. About two minutes at end which give one a warm feeling. But apart from that it is all rather painful and unsettling.

It's tricky really. I could understand if someone HATED this movie to shreds. It has lacklustre pace to it. But if I am honest, this movie is totally and incredibly unique that it has to be admired. The acting, the pure physical and perfect acting and dialogue is what made this movie. Nothing spoken was wasted into thin air just to fill time, it all had meaning. Oh, and again superb directing from Danny Boyle and crew...this movie looked gorgeous and it's resolution was quite beautiful if a little more heart than the 1st and 2nd act, which I would've liked to of seen.

With a terrific central performance from Michael Fassbender, 'Steve Jobs' is exactly what you'd expect from a collaboration between Danny Boyle and Aaron Sorkin, even if the second act slightly sags and the secondary characters could have been fleshed out a little more.

the whole movie is spent walking behind him trying to reason with him and dialog informing the viewer of the backstory. Almost no actual action - just boring and obvious backstory explaining. Throw in some psychobabble and efforts at softening his unbelievably prickly narcissistic personality and that's about the whole movie. Skip it.

"Fictional realism" as I would have put it, Steve Jobs condenses Jobs' signature emotional hurricane, his vision, his relationships with people close to him into a nice 3-act movie. I appreciated little things I'd expect to see, like how Jobs cleans his feet in the toilet or how Jobs tends to view things as either "insanely great" or unacceptable, indicating high quality coming from the screenwriter.
three and a half stars (7/10)

Boyle's fast pace direction and Sorkin's no bullshit dialogue gel perfectly here and what may have been the quickest 2 hours of my life. The timeline covered of Jobs life is a perfect encapsulation of what made the man most interesting.

This was never ever going to be a bad movie. Danny Boyle directs an Aaron Sorkin script starring "the Fass". It's a cool, interesting, emotional movie that features a powerful but nuanced performance from Fassbender. Sorkin's script is typically taut....
One millionaire's struggle to become a billionaire.

I liked this movie, but I feel like it could have been better. There is some really interesting dialogue and camera work, with excellent actors, but I felt like in the end I just didn't care enough. The structure of the movie felt forced, and as much as I love Kate Winslet I found her accent inconsistent.
This film is a tour de force for all involved. The actors disappear into their roles, the writing crackles, and Boyle's direction ties it all together with his trademark style.

Maybe the best movie of the year so far. Extremely engaging and entertaining dialogues, elegantly directed and sublimely performed by an outstanding cast. It would have been perfect but for some unnecessary cheesiness at the end.

The performances and direction are all top notch, of course; but the star here is the screenplay. Never has a biopic been more exciting and engaging from the get-go. If Sorkin's writing doesn't bring home Oscar gold, it will be the snub of the century.

After exposing myself to a seemingly end series of cinematic horrors (The Martian, Johnny Depp's crappier version of The Departed, Crimson Peak, the Polish Oscar candidate 11 minutes, and the new Bond movie that looked like Sam Mendes decided to take random scenes out of Bond films from the 1970s to avoid having to write a script), finally a movie that once again made me excited about being in the cinema, rather than just sleepy! Written by Aaron Sorkin, now officially an expert in scripting biopics of computer geeks with big egos, Steve Jobs, like its protagonist, doesn't leave anything to chance. The actors are of top quality, the script and dialogue precise as clockwork, and the music and cinematography incredibly atmospheric. This movie is relentless, and despite its only action scene being that of Jobs doing stretches, it leaves the audience on the edge of their seats for over two hours. The only complaints I might have is that a few scenes are overly stylized, contrasting with the naturalistic acting, as well as Kate Winslet's atrocious Polish accent, but this is nit-picking. Great film!

VIEWS ON FILM review by Jesse BurlesonIf not for Danny Boyle's grainy, pronounced direction, the routine for Steve Jobs (my latest review) would grow rather tiresome. For the most part, this is a real ball breaker of a movie, a character study that aches and moans. Every scene is a frigid confrontation, every dramatis personae is a painstaking resolve, and every bit of dialogue written by Aaron Sorkin, strands of hurried validity (remember the jibber jabber in 2010's The Social Network?).Anyway, if you decide to take in a viewing of "Jobs", you'll be doing what other patrons (and actual extras for the film) will be doing, looking from the outside in. This closed-off production masked as cinematic agoraphobia, has performances in it that I would categorized as master class. You don't see the wheels turning in any trouper's head. Heck, you don't see anyone really acting at all (this is a compliment).Now Steve Jobs the movie, is about the non-fictional Steve Jobs, an American businessman and co-founder of Apple Inc. He died before he reached the age of 60, fathering a daughter he claimed wasn't his, creating a computer that could talk, and achieving a net worth of millions upon millions of dollars. The vehicle doesn't delve into his later years when his health declined (due to pancreatic cancer). And it doesn't give us a highlight reel of him inventing the iPod, iPhone, or iTunes. No this is a two-hour running time of Steve's life, spliced into three days within three different years (early 80's launch of the Apple Macintosh, 1988's launch of NeXT Computer, and 1998's premier of the iMac). Here, San Francisco's adopted son is portrayed as sullen and forthright, a miserable human being. He's the smartest a-hole in the room and he freaking knows it. In terms of casting, Michael Fassbender shines in the lead role, Kate Winslet is almost unrecognizable playing Steve's marketing director, Seth Rogen comes into his own as Steve's rival/erstwhile collaborator, and Jeff Daniels adds on to his dramatic chops (just like in The Martian) channeling Apple Inc.'s former CEO (John Sculley). In the realm of structure, there are some swift flashbacks towards the end (Jobs and his daughter revisit their lost moments), some longer flashbacks sprinkled throughout (everything happening before 1984), a complex screenplay that sort of recycles itself, and sequences where actors talk as if it's merely for sport. My favorite line is when Jobs quips, "musicians play their instruments, I play the orchestra". Slammer!All in all, this is Boyle's twelfth flick to date. It pays homage to Arthur C. Clarke, gives a good-natured ribbing to Mr. Bill Gates, and has an unconcerned sense of time and place. In my opinion, it was probably released too early this year (October 9th to be exact). Here's hoping the Academy voters don't ignore "Jobs", actor Michael Fassbender, and actress Kate Winslet come January (their work deserves surefire award nominations). Bottom line: Steve Jobs is lean, mean Oscar bait yet it doesn't promote it, it earns it. Dialogue-driven, frustrating, exhausting, and psychologically formidable, you can already put it on my list of 2015's best films. Rating: 3 and a half stars.

A well-oiled machine with a brilliant (if schematic) screenplay, fluid camerwork and a crackerjack cast; the film almost overcomes the fact that it's about a borderline sociopath with no people skills. We should care why?
Superb performances, unexpectedly beautiful camera work, and an intelligent well written script. Highly recommend this movie if you like smart movies.

The whole thing takes place at a series of launches for Job's products, and once you realize that you're never going to get outside, or go anywhere, or get to know anyone except through very artificial dialogue, poorly used flashbacks and Sorkinesque claptrap, you tune out. At least this viewer did. The father daughter relationship, which should have been a slam dunk for me, felt manipulative and forced even though the young actresses playing the daughters were good. And I can't imagine why Kate Winslet said she just had to play her role, all she did was run around after Jobs calling, "Steve! Steve!" much the way she used to constantly call out "Jack! Jack!" in another well-remembered film, which is looking better in retrospect.

The movie raised many questions about the man of Steve Jobs, though spent too much time focusing on dialogue and the Apple 2. It was well written though had a terrible ending. I believe a third Act showing the outcome of Steve Jobs would be beneficial and that the ending was like taking an electroencephalogram.

It's an action movie where words have replaced bullets. That's the best metaphor I can think of.This is tied with the amazing "Pirates of Silicon Valley" for the best movie about the rise of tech, and easily the best representation of Jobs for both his pros and cons. Kate Winslett and Michael Fassbender's performances are truly riveting. The plot itself is structured very much like a 3-act play and seems to tie things up a little bit too neatly and tidily. One gets the impression that this is not a true to life portrayal of all the nuances of Jobs' complicated life.

Amazingly executed. Well shot. Thrilling performances by Fassbender, but more so Winslet. The frenetic pacing of the film was brilliant because it reflected Jobs' frenetic mind. The only issue was that the staged quality of the film gives it the feeling of a play, almost. It's very artificial. Also, I would go so far as to say that this is not a biopic, but rather an artistic interpretation of Steve Jobs's life. That's how practically and stylistically removed from reality it is. Still, great film.

Minutes before the launch of the Macintosh back in 1984, Jobs is agitated by the designer's inability to make the device say Hello. That unwarranted obsession in reality, was his passionate vision that became the legacy of the iCEO. Walter Isaacson captured the essence of the genius entrepreneur's journey from his garage up until his last days after the introduction of the Ipad 2. However, the adaptation by Andy Sorkin restricts our insight into the character and his legacy as it focuses more on his struggles as a reluctant father and as a failed CEO. Danny Boyle ('Slumdog Millionaire', '127 hours') had to extract the best out of Michael Fassbender and the supporting actors to capture our attention in this one-dimensional biography and with some sharp dialogues, they do have a riveting effect.The first among the three product launches in the film's narrative centers around the Macintosh and more importantly, Jobs' interaction with Chrisann (Katherine Waterston) and their daughter Lisa, whom he refuses to acknowledge as his own. Jobs' nonchalant and unkind mannerism towards his daughter makes complete sense when he is portrayed as a prick with the Apple team. Sorkin unabashedly focuses our attention to this side of Steve Jobs and offers little insight into the reason behind such behaviors. Adopted at an early age after being abandoned by his birth parents, Jobs' acrimony pretty much takes over the entire film's narrative. The first act also portrays his persistence for achieving the details that wouldn't really matter to the end user but they are primal in his vision. Just when Jobs was to appear on stage to unveil the Macintosh to the crowd, the director jumps to highlight the product's dismal sales performance that eventually led to Apple firing its very co-founder.Four years later, Jobs' interaction with Lisa about the perfect cube and her mother's negligent parenting is interrupted by Joanna Hoffman (Kate Winslet), prompting him to prepare for a couple of meetings before he gets on stage to launch the ridiculously overpriced, NeXT Cube. In a heated scene, Steve Wozniak (Seth Rogen) warns him of the Cube's imminent failure due to its price and market, to which, Jobs pays little heed. Product aesthetics and end-to-end control were at the core of his products while Woz tried to alter his ways to make products successful by making them more changeable. If this argument was heated, then the five minutes with the 'Newsroom' star Jeff Daniels who plays Apple CEO John Sculley, is simply screen-scorching. One man tries to justify why he did what he had to while the other looks for closure from his past failure. His moments with a very concerned Joanna, reveal his broad intentions and astute business mind. The screenplay then jumps to the epic failure of the product that was renowned in the computing industry for years to come.Having been re-hired as then struggling Apple's CEO in 1998, Jobs is about to get on stage to unveil the industry shaking iMac but he must first confront Woz yet again and a grown up Lisa who now shares a much stronger bond with her father. The film closes on the triumphant turning point that would mark new beginnings for Jobs' career as an innovative CEO and for his bond with the daughter he has finally come to acknowledge.The iMac went on to become hugely successful and it laid the foundation for Apple Computers which then became the hub for industry changing innovations. Sadly, this tip of the iceberg is all that the film showcases about the iconic thinker and his company's successes. Sorkin and Danny Boyle take their creative liberties to not only dramatize the failures of Steve Jobs but also digress from Isaacson's book to lean into the one-dimensional portrayal of the struggling father, failed CEO and ungrateful friend. Such deviations and liberties are acceptable in biopics that don't have two hours of exciting material but ending the story about Steve Jobs back in 1998, just when the world started recognizing his true genius, is risky and honestly unfulfilling.Steve Jobs may have been a prick with his social skills but his intention was only to pursue the unthinkable and achieve the extraordinary with his team. Only the thick skinned folk around him survived his lashing and they turned out to be the successors of his legacy of crowd pleasing innovation. Michael Fassbender is genuinely, the film's stronghold. His performance is fierce in its sincerity to the portrayal, his understanding of Steve Jobs' passion behind innovating is depicted with the persistence that comes from a mature actor. He is quite straightforward being acrimonious and he makes it look totally normal. This should, at the very least, earn Fassbender a nomination for the best actor.Jeff Daniels comes to his best in the heated confrontation with Fassbender and the scene just electrifies with intensity. Seth Rogen is mostly himself but his disbelief of Jobs' stubbornness is what he plays all along while being supportive to his friend. Michael Stuhlbarg as Andy Hartzfeld portrays the recipient of Steve Jobs' lashing that result from his obsessive innovation standards.Kate Winslet balances the tension, frustration and precarious nature of her CEO but being bold enough to challenge him especially when it concerns his daughter Lisa. As Hoffman, she stands out as a tough woman in business and more so by her well maintained composure. Danny Boyle's captivating direction includes a variety of filters, lighting and close ups. Andy Sorkin's screenplay shows us his perspective of Steve Jobs which isn't completely fulfilling for those who would've preferred a complete insight into the character. However, the film is a riveting watch because of the powerhouse of performances especially from Michael Fassbender. This may not be the last film about the world's most talked about tech innovator and CEO and it very well shouldn't be. - 7.681 on a scale of 1-10.

Another walking while talking Sorkin dialogue delight but this time the stakes are highest and most interesting in the second act and the it is left to Kate Winslet to create drama in a third act that really doesn't have any. By the time we get to the "recognizable/successful" Jobs the drama is over.
This movie was such a let down especially if you have read the book. Waste of time and money!

People have asked frequently what I thought of the film Steve Jobs, most of them expecting a long-winded, nuanced answer full of qualifiers, as is my custom. Everyone has been floored by my simple and firm response. It's fucking PERFECT. I have hesitated to pen this review for fear of sounding pedantic, fawning, or trite. But there is is no avoiding the inevitable. Steve Jobs is finest example of acting and screenwriting we are to receive this year. Period. This film takes a theatrical approach and delivers a variation of a traditional three-act play. Rather than try to take on the broad narrative of our protagonist's life story while worshipping Apple (as the overly hagiographic Jobs did a few years earlier), each act takes place directly before a public launch event. This particular choice is no accident, as Steve Jobs is widely recognized for being a master of theatrics and stagecraft. Steve Jobs is channeled in fine form by Michael Fassbender, who has quietly become the world's best underrated actor. His Jobs is deeply intelligent, narcissistic, manipulative, ambitious, and a committed and uncompromising strategist. It's no mistake that Steve silently looks upon a painting of Napoleon Bonaparte and ponders his future. We also see much of his philosophy and business strategy, such as accessibility over versatility, design over function, and aesthetics over hardware, to the chagrin of many of the supporting characters. Independent film queen Kate Winslet manages to issue great back-and-forth, rapid-fire dialog as Jobs' long suffering assistant. The direction by Danny Boyle is fantastic and micro-focused, not a scene wasted or needed. The script, curtesy of Aaron Sorkin, represents his best work since The Social Network and it's hard not to see the parallels in terms of the themes presented and the real life giants they tackle. One particular scene stood out to me in which Jobs and his former CEO, played by Jeff Daniels engage in a brutal argument. While most would see only two white guys in suits arguing in an empty room with a few chairs, I saw a vicious lightsaber duel to the death. The dialog give a no-holds barred gritty feel and the scene had me more tensed and riveted than any action movie thus year, save Mad Max: Fury Road. One might be tempted to call this ACTING: THE MOVIE.Other subplots proved to be rewarding as well, such as the odd relationship between Jobs and his daughter (three different actresses) which gives him a true arc by humbling him, forcibly, and bringing him full circle with his life decisions. He also shares a critical trait with the main characters of Citizen Kane, Raging Bull, and the Social Network in that the skills and abilities that make him succeed professionally, doom him in his personal life. Jobs even admits that he is "poorly made." There are numerous other performances by character actors such as Seth Rogen that complete it so perfectly, but it would take another 3 paragraphs to do them justice. I can simply reiterate that Steve Jobs is lean, well-crafted masterpiece that deserves more attention and every award that it will be nominated for. See it. Absorb it. Think different.

Yes, I enjoyed it, more or less. I'm a believer. But by the third preposterous act, this became so predictably Aaron Sorkin I wanted to scream. Leave aside that none of those people were likely to show up thirty minutes before a product launch, much less chose that moment to engage in a life-changing personal one-on-one rap, some of them weren't even in his life by then. And if they did/had, they sure wouldn't talk like Sorkin writes them. They might as well have been dashing down the hallways of the West Wing or across the set of the evening news. It's all the same to him, a chance to pontificate. Poetic license is one thing.Tendentiousness is another thing entirely, and Sorkin never fails.

Wonderful movie. I was engaged the entire time. Well-acted. Well-executed. Extremely witty dialogue. I guess the scope had to be as narrow as it was in this movie in order to go deeper into the story lines they chose to include in the movie. They completely left out Pixar, his wife, Laurene, the cancer, and it stops just short of the ipod. We never get past those multi-colored Apple computers when Jobs returns to Apple. It focuses mostly on his relationship with the daughter used to deny and his relationship with Apple -- him hiring Scully, and then Scully kicking him out, and how he returned. As a movie, STEVE JOBS is great. Potentially boring conversations sizzle electrically. An almost completely unlikeable character* is made extraordinarily compelling, both on the page and in an award-worthy performance by Michael Fassbender. I could watch the characters in STEVE JOBS all day.However, as a biopic, it is openly contemptuous of its subject. Charisma aside, it makes no bones about the fact that it thinks Jobs was a terrible boss and a terrible father. (I invariably got in right when Jobs started NeXT, so it's possible he is shown to be good at something in the first half.) As a reflection of reality, it's disgusting in its hypocrisy. It spends at least half an hour in an ongoing argument between Jobs and Steve Wozniak about whether Jobs should acknowledge the legacy of the Apple II, coming down hard against Jobs' refusal to do so. Unfortunately, it fails to acknowledge that while Jobs was a terrible father to his first, out-of-wedlock daughter (which is true), he also had three other kids, with another woman, his wife, to whom he was by all accounts very good.This one-sided contempt while presenting its own point of view as a more complete picture of reality disgusts me. See it for the movie. Avoid it for the moralizing hypocrisy.*I didn't get to see the first 3/4 hour or so, so I don't know if it tried to make him likeable in there. Also now you know that I didn't see the whole movie, so do with this review what you want.

This was a simplistic movie at its core. Jobs, over a period of time, is about to showcase a new product in front of hundreds. Before the unveiling of whatever new technology exists within the scene, Jobs has various frustrating arguments with people in his life. It starts and ends on this note, essentially, with almost the whole plot based on those few moments before he is about to go on stage. It hardly gets into his interest in Buddhism and Hinduism, and only has a few scenes of the very beginning of what led to one of the most important people in the last century.The acting, enthusiastic response from the crowd as they awaited him to walk on stage, and basic plot was interesting enough, but it hardly got into depth in who this person was. Much like after watching Kerouac, I do not see him as a anything more than a megalomaniac after watching this. It's a very surface film, mainly focusing on his relationships. I am not even a techie, but living in the Northwest I have friends who are, and some who possibly even rubbed elbows with Jobs, so I expected a bit more insight into this world I feel so distant from. On this note, it failed. The dramas are enough to draw in most, as well as the decent camera work, but overall this is hardly an insight into this persons life. One of the main components of Jobs interest in computers was each individual having the ability to acceess what Jobs considered the greatest tool yet conceived. It only touched on this brilliant idea, and its portrayal of the man put him in a very unfavorable light.

Aaron Sorkin's writing was interesting, and made for some good story telling. Fassbender is always good, but he did not draw in this audience member, as I didn't find any human qualities about his portrayal of Jobs that made me want to make a personal connection. Jobs' well-known arrogance and straight out abusive behavior for those most close in his life are once again in the fore front, but not in a way that make you empathize with his suffering. The film repeatedly references this through his discussions with Scully (Jeff Daniels- who is excellent in this role), but does not do enough to support a human connection to the little boy who never feels parental love. Instead, I found myself ever more anxious and agitated both by the film's myopic views via the lens of each launch, and the seeming lack of growth or ability for emotional growth in this main character, and man who changed much of our own worlds. STEVE JOBS, whatever else it may be, exists as a spectacular showcase for (primarily) two people - its writer, Aaron Sorkin, and its leading man, Michael Fassbender. Sorkin's script is perhaps the most Sorkiny thing he's yet written (which is really saying something), as it presents characters operating at an incredibly high level of verbal dexterity, and the result is simply a joy to behold, not merely a great screenplay, but an extraordinary screenplay. The dialogue is dense and rapid fire, giving the movie a feeling of breathless pace, no small accomplishment for a story mostly featuring people talking in rooms, the characterization of the title character is deeply complex and nuanced, and the narrative structure is fascinating and allows the audience to truly see this set of characters change over the course of 14 years (the structure also allows each of the three primary acts to reflect and echo each other in compelling and affecting ways). Director Danny Boyle does fine work in giving each of the acts its own visual and editorial flavor, but he also doesn't indulge in flamboyance for the sake of it; at its heart, this is a screenplay that could easily be adapted for the stage, and Boyle wisely respects that and doesn't mess too much with it trying to impart stylistic tics. As Jobs, Fassbender graces us with perhaps his finest performance to date, an instantly iconic portrait of a complicated, difficult, and visionary man who seemed to operate on a higher level than just about everyone else around him. There's a passion and keen intellect brought to the role by Fassbender that by all rights should see him highly praised come awards season; it is the performance of the year thus far. He's backed up by a host of (nearly) equally fine performances, particularly those from Kate Winslet (somehow being both totally harried and yet utterly in total control), Seth Rogen (shockingly affecting and affable), Michael Stuhlbarg (perhaps the movie's secret comedic weapon), and Jeff Daniels (an equally weary and optimistic father figure). I think there's a very real possibility some could view the film as "boring," since its entire focus is in people simply having conversations, but I found it electrifying and exciting at all times, and to watch such sharp minds spar with each other is truly a pleasure. STEVE JOBS is the most cerebral movie of 2015 and - therefore - one of the best.
Probably closer to a 3.5 / 5.0, but I am a sucker for Sorkin's quick back-and-forth dialogue and I also have a man-crush on Fassbender...

Truly understand that Sorkin is not trying to create a biopic, a monster or a hero. Apple is more of an event than just a company. Sorkin choreographs the script capturing that dynamic and theme (not history), making you want to go read the real story if you haven't already. First off let me say I'm not an Apple guy, not because I have anything against Apple, just have never been able to afford their products. Not sure if that matters here, but this is the only Steve Jobs movie I have seen even though it is the third. There's a lot to like about Steve Jobs the movie, but there is also plenty I didn't. First the good lies in a great job by this cast, I mean I think they nailed their performances. This is a talkie for sure and it is put together pretty well with a splash of back story that remains interesting somewhat. I say somewhat because after a while I felt like I was watching Grounghog Day. You know that movie where the same thing keeps happening over and over. This movie has three acts, around the launch of three Steve Jobs lead products, and we get the same scenarios with the same people all three times. I think it's unique in how to tell his story, but after a while I grew tired of it. I'm not sure you can watch this thing and not come away from it thinking Steve Jobs is a giant pain in the rear. It's a well put together movie, but just didn't resonate with me the way I had hoped.

I thought this movie was very well done. It didn't try to whitewash someone who clearly had issues dealing relating to people but it also allowed the audience a glimpse into who Steve Jobs was. The cast all did a great job and I would easily recommend this movie!

I won't pretend like this film is not entertaining or well-made. But for me, this is an example of a talented writer over-writing. Aaron Sorkin can be one of the most engaging and brilliant writers when he's on his game, but it can get to his head sometimes. Every major character in this movie is smart, quick-witted, and fast-talking, which makes them nearly indistinguishable from one another as people. There is no room for subtlety, nuance, or reflective silence. It all seems like it's just a bunch of Aaron Sorkins walking around talking to each other very quickly, and considering that this is supposed to paint a portrait of a real man, it only succeeds in leaving the viewer with the impression that he -- Steve Jobs -- acted like an Aaron Sorkin character.
While it might not be his definitive biopic, Steve Jobs showcases Fassbender and Winslet at their best with an impeccable script about a flawed but human visionary.
Sorkin is a genius. Fassbender is a genius. Winslett nailed it. Such a great movie.

Steve Jobs as a film was probably a dream gig for the actors. There is a lot of dialog moving very quickly. It can be a challenge to keep up. The film doesn't lend itself to being all that much to look at. Fassbender is at the center of it all, and is really the propeller for all other movement. He all motion with little to no stillness. So where are the subtleties? Jeff Daniels does great in what feels like his character from Newsroom. Kate Winslet bangs out a great east european hint of accent. Does the film's reach match the grasp. Pretty much, but I don't think it exceeds it in telling me more about the modern legend.

A powerful and thought-provoking film, Steve Jobs accomplishes everything it's trying to accomplish. Taking place over the course of 14 crucial years in the life of one of history's greatest innovators, Steve Jobs takes the smart approach towards encompassing such a life through three well-connected and powerful acts to examine the flawed man behind all complex wiring. Danny Boyle's fabulous direction and Aaron Sorkin's timely and entertaining script, coupled with the film's three act structure of product unveilings, create a modern Shakespearean drama of epic proportions, driven by characters and dialogue which could all be the Bard's work. Michael Fassbender's performance as Jobs is astounding and Oscar-worthy, portraying the man as more of a robot or machine who isn't compatible with other human beings. His transformation over the course of the film is hard to see at times on account of Fassbender's excellent work to make him a character you only sometimes root for. With the impressive supporting cast of Kate Winslet as Job's sympathetic and flustered assistant, Seth Rogen as Steve Wozniak, the Lennon to Jobs' McCarthy who Jobs treats like his Ringo and Jeff Daniels as John Scully, the man who helped Jobs become what he is but had to turn his back on him. As a character study and film, Steve Jobs is a journey of understanding which brings you closer to the man and away from the myth.
Rogen ruins every film he's in. It's mildly interesting to see him playing an adolescent pothead throughout his entire life. What kind of a contribution is that to cinematic art?
Despite having good performances from nearly everyone involved, the script sometimes makes Steve Jobs feel like the least interesting man in the room compared to his Apple comrades.

Watching the STEVE JOBS biopic directed by Danny Boyle and written by Aaron Sorkin was a nostalgic experience, bringing me back in time to 1992 when I purchased my first Apple Computer which regretfully turned out to be a "rotten apple with so many problems that Apple's headquarters sent a technician to my home in NJ to change the "motherboard." This was the "dark phase" of the company when it was on the downswing - the percentage of Apple users were declining and IBM's P.C.'s were on the rise. Because my "mentor" was a rabid supporter - never wavering in his belief in Steve Jobs and Apple products, I too followed his lead despite the fact that Jobs was not with the company having been "fired" in 1985. The film STEVE JOBS gives us a glimpse into the man who today is considered a visionary having changed the way we communicate and navigate the world.I once wrote a Letter to the NY Times extolling the power of film "... to re-vise, re-invent and re-position history and historical figures within popular culture... Too often ideas, whether they be political or cultural, permeate into the general consciousness through the membrane of a director..." And this holds true for director Danny Boyle's depiction of Steve Jobs. There is a frenetic pace to the film - and Boyle uses the moments before the presentation of new products to an audience of devotees as a vehicle "exposing" the complexity of Steve Jobs' personal and professional history. The dramatic focus of the movie STEVE JOBS hinges upon 3 major "computer launch" events - the original Macintosh in 1984 in competition with the Apple II - the commercial bedrock of the company; the unveiling of NeXT cube in 1988 - what it did is still a mystery; and the beautifully designed iMac in 1998 - the start of the innovational "iEra". The products were an extension of the man himself - a person who controlled every aspect of his brand - obsessively committed and singleminded - never one to compromise - as witnessed by his battles with childhood friend and co-founder Steve Wozniak - Seth Rogan doing a great job as this decent, burly "nuts and bolts" man who actualizes Jobs' idealistic concepts. Michael Fassbender is excellent as Jobs - cool, detached and charismatic encased in armor that is rarely penetrated except by the always-by-his side assistant Joanna Hoffman (a staid and respectful Kate Winslet with a weird undertone of an accent) and his daughter Lisa, (whose paternity he once renounced,) - a pivotal character functioning as a catalyst and humanizing foil to the self-absorbed and fervid Jobs.There is a claustrophobic feel to the film - an undercurrent of acute tension created by Job's contentious and truculent interactions with his colleagues and family; the need to micro-manage every one of life's moments leaving no room for respite - we the audience suffer from the lack of air. I also left the theater wondering WHAT exactly did Jobs do as co-founder of Apple Inc.outside of being a genius marketing promoter?  I recommend reading Walter Isaacson's authorized biography of Steve Jobs, particularly after seeing a movie which gives you a narrow, surface view of an impassioned man who deserves to be seen more fully to understand his historical importance as that rare individual whose accomplishments touched people all over the globe. Regrettably STEVE JOBS gives very little inkling of the man who anticipated much of the 21st century's technological innovations.

Cool way to do a biopic, though a little too transparent at one moment ("Why do people keep coming to me 5 minutes before my presentations?")I know everybody's mentioned it, but I really couldn't get over Michael Fassbender's face for half the movie, and then I felt like he had a weird accent for the last act. I don't know what I was hearing. He did a great job though. I don't know if it was an accurate version of Steve or not, but it sure was dramatic and entertaining to watch.I loved how the film style and score changed with the times.Overall, a good popcorn flick.

This is not a movie about a company, or products, or even people. It's a paean to a person who was the most successful appropriator of others' intellectual property in history. Some have said that this was an unsympathetic film, taking a hard look at his relationships with his Apple compatriots and his daughter. I say the viewpoint taken is far too sympathetic. I'm still waiting for the movie that depicts Steve Jobs as the master of others' ideas, whose main skill was to commercialize something around his own cult of personality and call it his own inspiration, and whose life reflects the worst of humanity. Otherwise, Fassbender gives a barely believable performance as Jobs, while Seth Rogan hits it out of the park with his portrayal of Steve Wozniak and Jeff Daniels plays himself as John Scully so damn well. No, I will not be buying the DVD, t-shirt, or the field guide to the reality distortion field.

Without Aaron Sorkin's terrific, eargasm-inducing script, this film wouldn't have been as great as it is. The unconventional structure, the train of unstoppable dialogue, and the complexities of its titular character, it is nothing but sheer brilliance. Fassbender looks nothing like Jobs, but it doesn't matter a bit. He embodies the charisma and elegance of Jobs, as well as his uglier and more vulnerable side. And kudos to Danny Boyle for his speedy and energetic direction, masterfully orchestrating a group of brilliant actors and taking the best out of them. This is not a straightforward biopic; it is a challenging film, and not for the lazy ass who prefers the conventional Hollywood storytelling. Sorkin fires up on all cylinders, and demands you to keep up with it. Steve Jobs is written, directed, and acted to perfection. It is audacious, intelligent, and absolutely riveting. One of the best films of 2015, and I cannot wait to watch it again and again and again and again and again. It is fantastic.
This movie was pretty bad. See something else.

In a word, boring. This film focuses on three "important" product launches in Jobs' career. The acting was great. Everyone in this film was convincing in their role and I'll expect Oscar noms for a few. But where the movie loses me is the story. This is not a film about Steve Jobs' life or the history of Apple but more about a slice of his career. Every scene is set inside an auditorium, either backstage, on stage, or in a hall. This would make a great theatre play but as a motion picture it's just dull.
Clever screenplay. Excellent adaption from the book, following Jobs' own breakdown of his career into 3 product annnouncments.

I was on the margins of one of his plow-ups at NAB and suffered the effects of his "use your partners and then kill them" style... An accurate, entertaining and emotional picture of the man and his time.

Touching, emotional, and convincing. Steve Jobs was a fantastic movie, save for a few boring moments, full of incredible acting and a well put together script. Michael Fassbender played Steve Jobs surprisingly well. The other actors did a fantastic job playing their part. The arguments portrayed throughout the movie (and there are a lot of them) didn't feel forced and ridiculous, actually, they felt amazingly intense and I enjoyed every minute of it, not knowing what would be lashed out next. The flashbacks were well timed. Music was fantastic. The only flaw this movie had were some moments in which I felt bored, otherwise, great movie with a truly touching ending.
Abhorrent cinema. Kitschy.
Flagrant and damaging misrepresentation of a cultural icon. Thumbs down.

Steve Jobs is a movie about ... wait for it ... Steve Jobs. But more to the point this is a movie about some of the decision making of Steve Jobs as told through vignettes from minutes before three different product launches ... the Mac, the Next and the iMac.The movie has the typical Aaron Sorkin patter which is what really drew me to see yet another Steve Jobs story and in this regard, doesn't disappoint, However the story telling is a bit artsy for Sorkin and I don't think he quite carried it off as well as his previous endeavors. Additionally, this movie is more of a potential insight into the character (or lack thereof) of Steve Jobs rather than a real bio-pic. While the casting is great and all do terrific performances, I don't feel that they were remotely true to the characters they were playing. Rather is seems they were asked to play aspects of facets of Steve Jobs life and given familiar name tags (having met Steve Wozniak some time ago, I can attest he was never as well spoken as Seth Rogan).This is an enjoyable movie from the standpoint of the dialogue which one expects from Aaron Sorkin, However in the end, the story itself reveals little and is somewhat muttled and confused leaving the viewer with little more than Steve Jobs was a hugely egotistical control-freak. Then again maybe the story telling is spot on.

Steve Jobs is a triumphant, energetic, fast moving look at 3 days in the life of an arguable genius. Like Aaron Sorkin's previous script about an asshole genius (The Social Network), the titular character doesn't come across as all roses and sunshine. Indeed, he is difficult, rude, and oblivious to the effect he has on people. He is also insanely smart, passionate, and a huge perfectionist. Fassbender has impressed me with pretty much every role he has played in his career so far. With Steve Jobs, he tops that all. He makes Jobs a complex person who knows what he has to do, even at the peril of others. It helps that Fassbender is surrounded by a cast who are just as game as he is. Rogen is great, slightly against type, and some of the best scenes of the movie involve Jeff Daniels' Apple CEO John Scully and Jobs going head to head. Special attention, though, should be given to Kate Winslet who plays Jobs' right hand and is often tasked with the awful Job of cleaning up in Steve's wake. Props, too, should be given to director Danny Boyle who's electric direction drive this movie at 100mph at all times. Seriously, I need to see the movie again, as there was so much going on that is was hard to always have a 100 percent grasp on everything. Finally, major, major props should be given to Sorkin's screenplay which is concise but complex and always blindingly intelligent. As it stands, Steve Jobs is a brilliant movie about a brilliant, difficult genius who may have ushered in the age we live in.
Loved how the movie was structured--this way it could spend more time focusing on its subject character rather than retelling his whole life story. Michael Fassbender was exceptional as Steve Jobs!
Worst movie I have seen in my life. Don't watch it even if they pay you.

This is the most inaccurate film I have ever watched. It is complete slander against Steve Jobs. If you have ever read Walter Isaacson's biography of him, you will realize how biased this film is and that it is a complete fabrication of who Steve Jobs was. Please avoid watching this at all costs.

Danny Boyle and Aaron Sorkin's bio-pic on computer businessman Steve Jobs is certainly a customary job from the two artists. Painting their subject in a less than savory light, viewers may be surprised to find how little sympathy this film attempts towards Steve Jobs (aside from a fairly goopy conclusion), but there in lies the film's strongest card. It's a vivid character study, with the unmistakable Sorkin dialogue and Boyle visuals visible really allowing it to resonate, and the film's play-like approach to the acts (all three represent a different iconic launch in his life) certainly gives it prestige points. It's not as universal as the Social Netowork (which succeeded in being an entertaining bio-pic, as well as a transgressive look on how technology affects humanity), but it's a formidable film that will last beyond awards season.

Cast, director, and writer turn three product launches into hefty battles of words. Sorkin's dialogue is on point, except when he has Steve Jobs turn into a busy body and makes people follow him through hallways as they talk. This makes it seem less like a biopic, but it still has really strong acting and direction from Danny Boyle. The result is a stimulating look at a brilliant marketer who would literally change the faces of personal computers, also with some added subplots about his estranged daughter. Even though you'd think the subject matter would bore you, the way its presented makes it engaging and engrossing.

"Steve Jobs" is a character study about the co-founder of Apple Computers and his nuanced personalities. The film finds him on the verge of releasing his latest prototype, and the film is a dramatization of the different aspects of his life and what makes him tick. The acting in this movie is top-notch. Kate Winslet shines as the foil in the movie to Michael Fassbender's Jobs, and even Seth Rogen shows his versatility as an actor. The acting is fine. Where this movie gets dicey is the execution. There are too many thematic elements in the movie, and the movie is largely melodramatic. There are too many monologues, which make the movie extremely maudlin and tedious. The movie moves at too fast a clip and consists largely of arguments Jobs had with people around him. The movie doesn't do nearly enough to focus on Jobs' accomplishments but rather paints him as a whiney, self-righteous little dipshit. I had high expectations for this movie. I wouldn't mind some acting nominations, but this movie is nowhere near best picture material for me --------------------------------------------------------------------- C+

Well acted, but ultimately repetitive, talky and emotionally cool and exhausting, this film arguably probably would work better on stage where the limitations of its central conceit might not stifle the supporting players so much.

Loved this movie! Brilliantly directed by Danny Boyle (127 Hours, Slumdog Millionaire) and screenplay by Aaron Sorkin. Michael Fassbender is on his usual stellar game as Steve Jobs and Kate Winslet is also her usual fantastic self as Joanna Hoffman, his lifetime confidant. It's a 3-act film, set up by 3 major products launches by Jobs (Macintosh, NeXT and iMAC. It also portrays the relationship between Jobs and his daughter, Lisa Brennan-Jobs and their oft-torturous relationship. I HIGHLY recommend seeing it!
Terrible Movie Only showed half his life. Ended with his return to Apple. The most interesting part if his life was from the Ipod on to his death...Nothing to see here.

According to the most recent of several Apple-founder biopics, Steve Jobs the man (Fassbender) was a delusional, self-absorbed pioneer with a God-complex to end all god-complexes. He was a less-than-fun dude, to say the least. I'm also hyper-aware that the thoughts I had on his faulty and fruitful life were being noted on a device that he created, one that 40 years ago would've taken up a large conference room and now fits in my pocket. These huge revelations have become his legacy...but should they have? Fassbender, Boyle and writer Sorkin, each among the best at their jobs, propose that Steve's professional successes may have been the cause of his personal flaws.The plot is a screenwriting construction; set during three different product launches and the minutes that lead up to them, Jobs (barely) tries to balance his two children, the more important his current product. The entire film is Sorkin's patented "walking-and-talking" trademark, yet never drags even at its 2+ hours length. Director Boyle, while relatively restrained, finds plenty of appropriate moments to display his skill for visual pop. However, the main cinematic thrills all come from the dialogue, as if the words are explosions in an action movie. Some people criticize Sorkin (Social Network, "West Wing") because his dialogue doesn't feel natural, the rapacious repartee undercut by over-explanation, and moments standing out as feeling "written". However, I usually just find myself wishing my friends and I spoke the way he writes. Add in line-deliverers like Fassbender, Winslet, Rogen, Daniels, and Stuhlbarg, Jobs end result is a hypnotic and highly entertaining capsule of a man at the center of the computer generation.
I met Steve Jobs once. At a Grateful Dead show. Yes we were.

This isn't like most biopics, it just lingers on three events, product launches, in the life of its hero, the brilliant businessman behind Apple Computers. The script is fast-paced and packed with ideas, attitude, Silicon Valley history, and Steve Jobs biography. It kind of tells his story but mostly delves into his character through his relationships with family, employees, and his boss. It's very inventive and well-acted.

This film is loaded with sterling performances and some great speeches. It may even give a glimpse inside Jobs' personality. If it does, I'm really glad I didn't know him. This Jobs is a jerk, a snake oil salesman who is constantly trying to sell the same product and just waiting until technology and taste align to provide him with the opportunity to profit from it. It's a showcase for talented writing, directing and acting, but I almost wish I never saw it.
Loved how it portrayed him as the dick he was and not some saint who created the iPhone. Great movie.
