Also emotionally uninvolving. Danny Boyle is no David Fincher. And Boyle sure could have used Trent Reznor's help.

Fassbender steals the show with powerful acting and presence. Winslet does the best I've ever seen her do. Aaron Sorkin's screenplay is entertaining as usual but some moments drag on for too long and become dull. Overall, a solid film about a more personal side of Steve Jobs.

Fassbender perfectly captures the hubris of one of the 20th Century's great minds, but the script is hollow and the story serves only as a vehicle for Sorkin to spin his dizzyingly contrived brand of dialog. What we learn about Jobs, the company he built or the impact his revelatory products had I don't know. On these subjects the movie says surprisingly little. In the end we can deduce that Steve Jobs was a deeply flawed individual, as many of us are, who cared more about the impact his products made on the world, than he did about the impact that he made on the world and on those around him.

This movie has 3 main parts starting with him backstage at a lecture talking about Apple as a company and his intense desire for perfection. This does not paint him in a bad light but how Jobs demanded perfection from everyone and thought he could not be wrong. The other 2 parts are at two more of his speeches. It focuses on Jobs and his decline and second tenure with Apple. Steve Wozniak and John Sculley are huge characters along the way and how they impacted his professional relationship with Apple. Lastly it shows his early relationship with Chrisann Brennan and Lisa. I really enjoyed this film and the acting was superb. It is great for anyone but especially fans of Apple, people who want to know more about Steve Jobs and business minded people.

A nonlinear biopic masterfully crafted which presents a challenging portrayal of its subject through three acts. Despite an awkward stumble towards the end, it's one of the year's best.

The above line, which is the character Steve Jobs' (Michael Fassbender) explanation for why the Macintosh computer at the unveiling in 1984, is his reasoning, and it's the first time we see him in the movie and his super-demanding-behind-the-scenes self. He has to have the computer say "Hello" to the audience that will assemble and see his prized innovation (which he didn't all innovate by the way, but neither here nor there, at least to Jobs), and it has to break down how people have been shown computer systems in Hollywood movies. His marketing manager cum surrogate mother, Joanna Hoffman (Kate Winslet) remarks, "The computer in 2001 said hello, too. It scared the s*** out of me." There's another moment, a key one in a big, meaty exchange (what else does Sorkin love doing more) between Jobs and Wozniak in the auditorium in front of everybody, where Wozniak mentions that his products are better than the man who made them. Jobs agrees. Who is this a-hole? Our hero? Sort of, I guess.Aaron Sorkin once again gives us a guy who is a super-driven, I'll-do-it-MY-way-if-I-have-to self-professed genius, and perhaps it's hard to not think of Sorkin's Oscar-winning script for The Social Network with his version of Mark Zuckerberg (whether he really is or not I leave up to you dear reader). I could make a very long blog post showing the differences, but I think it comes down to something more elemental: Social Network is about friendship, or what would-be friendship is and as it breaks down (or wasn't there to start), and Steve Jobs is about marriages. Jobs's marriage to Joanna Hoffman, Jobs' marriage to Steve Wozniak, Jobs' marriage to Sculley, and even his sort of marriage to Any Herzfeld. But what about the woman who birthed his daughter ("She's not my daughter" he exclaims in 1984, and is one of the major conflicts of the film), or being a father to his daughter? And like marriages - till death do us part sort of thing - the same arguments and same old BS gets pulled up over and over again, even as technology changes and people age and move on to other companies.So we get three time frames here, which is clever until it becomes a little contrived. That sounds contradictory, but what I mean to say is that on the one hand, Sorkin and director Danny Boyle get to show something that a lot of biopics don't bother with when they go for the 'rise and fall' scenario - Jobs starts out at a point that is remarkable in 1984, about to launch the Macintosh computer, but with people all around him trying to get him to be... decent, to do the right things, to not keep doing s***y things (the Time magazine article, the Dylan lyrics signifying something, the mention for the Apple 2 people, the threat to Andy on the voice), and we see Steve interacting with everybody in the format that is what it is, a Backstage Melodrama. And yet we see the same arguments basically take place in 1988 and 1998. It IS the 'hard' parts of business/creative/personal "marriages". In short, this may or may not sound appealing.I feel like I may need to see the movie again for certain little things; I'm still not fully sold that the ending (or at least the final five/ten minutes, his resolution with Sculley and Lisa) don't dip more than a bit into making this character sympathetic - and I don't mean that as a bad thing, but that it feels shallow in a certain way, as in 'we've spent all this time telling you this guy's a d***, many times over, but... maybe he's deep down a really good guy.' On the other hand, it may not be that clear, and as I think on the movie there's ambiguity to certain moments and scenes, and that's what sticks with me and makes me interested to see it again.There's one little scene, where Jobs is talking to himself, softly, and repeating technical details on the iMac. Is he talking to himself to rehearse the lines - the actor as well as the "player of the Orchestra" as he puts it to Wozniak as what he *does*, which is still slightly vague by film's end aside from the aesthetic side - or is he genuinely concerned to get the tech stuff right, a nerd underneath the sleek exterior? Sorkin, I should mention again, loves gigantic, monumental confrontation scenes the way Ninja Turtles loves pizza; there are more than a few in this film, and a couple of them (Jobs and Sculley in 1988, Jobs and Wozniak in 1998) are the kind that become borderline too much to watch - the cutting back and forth in time is what makes it jarring in a good way, making the psychology and points of view distinct and interesting - but it's almost like Sorkin can't help himself, no restraint in the slightest. Nevertheless, Boyle and the producers got such a top shelf cast that even if this stuff was theatrical-grandstanding I'd be riveted. Fassbender, Winslet, Daniels, Waterston, and for sure Rogen (he's proved himself dramatically before, in Take This Waltz, and here he does it again) all pull off performances that make these words come alive and, really, human all around.What I mean by that last thing is that, it's one thing to read Sorkin's words - he writes what he does, and you'll know it by know from Social Network or his TV shows - but what Fassbender does here is incredible. If there's sympathy that Jobs gets, it's not so much in the writing as it is through just him, finding that pulse beneath the cold 'genius'. And Winslet's Joanna as the 'conscience' is spectacular, and often because she's just the one trying to keep things moving/together. Jobs needs that - how else will he give any kind of 'face' ala the computer screen?
They got 2 things right. His first name was Steve, and his last name was Jobs.

So bummed. I swear I feel like spent the past two hours harshing on a deceased beloved Uncle. It's almost sacrilegious in my opinion. This movie is allegedly about Steve Jobs, as indicated by the title, but it's really about a nasty man yelling at other people and being abusive and neglectful to his daughter. Enjoyed the acting of Michael Fassbender and Kate Winslet, but if you dont't know much about the whole Apple/Mac issues...it might not be worth your time. My opinion, wait for the DVD.
Deeply disturbing overview of a nihilistic egotist. What a genius, what a creep.

The acting in this film from everyone was honestly great, but that was it. Steve Jobs was such a remarkable mind, yet none captured that magic in the film. Apple is iconic and always will be for multiple reasons and I wanted to see the how he made it happen. Was he mind mapping, sketching or bouncing ideas constantly to come up with what he did. I wanted to see something inspiring that in years to come I would watch again because it moved me. The film felt negative and just sad once again. It would have been nice to have seen the positive side. The last film didn't really capture the visionary he was either although they did include the how on a couple things but still missing that effortless creation. Everyone knows that side of Steve Jobs already, and it would have been great to see and learn something different and embody hope for all the dreamers whom aspire to create.

No, Michael Fassbender doesn't look like Steve Jobs. No, not all the dialog actually took place. No, this is not a documentary, that was secretly filmed back stage while other events were taking place. It is a movie. It happens to be very well made, and poignant. It evokes a sense of time, and place. It is worth seeing, even if you are not a Steve Jobs or Apple fan. The Steve Jobs portrayed is not a saint, he is not even likable at times, but he is human, and that is what makes this movie great!

Although not looking like the Apple Co-Founder, Michael Fassbender is able to pull off the role in a story that was intelligent as it was compelling to showcase a much different side of the face we've come to know.

One of Aaron Sorkin's best scripts yet, bringing to life the extent of Jobs' misunderstood genius. Fassbender is, as always a powerhouse driving the film's stellar acting, and the supporting cast is brilliant by all means, however the film is 100% driven by the miraculous screenplay. It gives life and more depth to these real characters than anyone aside from their real-life family would expect.

Although it unfairly softens its blow a bit at the end, Steve Jobs is still a phenomenal film, propped up by some of the best dialogue Aaron Sorkin has ever penned to paint a picture of the man who created the Apple we see today, yet left miles of personal destruction in his wake. Michael Fassbender loses himself in the role of Jobs, while Seth Rogen and Michael Stuhlberg are also strong as Wozniak and Hertzfeldt.

Steve Jobs is the next attempt at a Steve Jobs autobiography directed by Danny Boyle and written by Aaron Sorkin. When this movie was first announced, I was really not interested. I had just seen 2013's Jobs and was not impressed. So, the idea of yet another one did not seem very appealing to me. But, then when Michael Fassbender was cast and I realized that Aaron Sorkin was the writer, I began to form high hopes. My expectations were exceeded in this unique and brilliant biography. Danny Boyle further proves himself as a wonderful director. Aaron Sorkin also has crafted an amazing screenplay with fantastic dialogue. Michael Fassbender gives one of the best performances in his career. He floored as Steve Jobs. Kate Winslet, Jeff Daniels, Seth Rogen, and Michael Stuhlbarg were all also fantastic. There is s much to love in this film, but, like most film, there is that one teeny tiny flaw that keeps it from being a masterpiece. The fact that all of the people in his life seem to decide to let out their feelings towards Steve Jobs before every major product launch. Although, this didn't bother me and shouldn't keep you from loving this movie. Overall, Steve Jobs is a near perfect film ith fantastic writing, acting, and directing.Rating: A

This is truly one of the best films that I've seen this year. No, Michael Fassbender doesn't look a think like Steve Jobs, at least until the end. But Fassbender captures the angst, the genius, and in something I truly didn't expect was able to humanize Steve more than anyone could've expected. Seth Rogen, in my humble opinion is the man to beat for best supporting actor, as he turns in an incredible performance as Steve Wozniak; and not to be outdone Kate Winslet shows that she's still capable of delivering incredible performances of her own; playing in many ways Steve's conscience in the film as Joanna Hoffman. Every bit as captivating as The Social Network, Steve Jobs is an absolute triumph.
I really enjoyed it, it's not really about the Business of Apple, but Steve's character and human interacting traits.... I really liked it

The direction and acting are the reason for the half star. The writing, while fast-paced and jargon-loaded, was so schlocky plot-wise. As if ex-girlfriends and bastard children are going to show up backstage before every product launch and Jobs is going to give them the time of day. I don't care if the President of the United States showed up just before a product launch. They were going to have to wait. What a contrived bunch of B.S. And the whole story arc with the daughter" "Love me daddy" with whkt's-her-name getting involved and insisting he do something as if she was anybody in real life. The whole thing was silly all the way up to the forced "tear-jerker" end where father and daughter make amends. I def was expecting more. Way more.

A fascinating three-act film. The decision to have the structure be three long scenes, each backstage before a big conference, was brilliant. The drama that occurs before each product launch is a bit heightened, but it serves well in portraying Steve's personality, and what it was like to work for him...according to them, of course. The performances are excellent, yes, even Rogen's... and they needed to be, this is a dialogue driven film after all.
I'm an avid movie-goer and I left and got a re-admit after 45 minutes. Horrible . . . too much "geek" talk that no one but engineers would understand or be interested in. Save your money.
Although the acting is pretty good, the story line is about 40% complete BS.

I've heard this described as "an action film with words instead of bullets" and i gotta say that is pretty accurate, Aaron Sorkin is back at it again, with my vote (as of now) for Best Adapted Screenplay of the year, the dialogue is very hard hitting, with several clever lines, and the actors deserve a lot of credit too for bringing them to life, Fassbender shines as always in the lead, in every single scene, and each of the supporting actors (Winslet, Daniels, Rogenm Stuhlbarg Waterston) all have their own quality exchanges with him, it's a bit of change of pace for director Danny Boyle, who usually does more adventurous films, but he manages to still insert some of his visual style in at parts, of the 3 act the film is divided into, Id say the 3rd is probably the weakest, prolly cuz its the least angry/intense, but its still good, Fassbender will surely get nominated for Best Actor, as well as Sorkin, and who knows how many others
