Haven't looked into the accuracy of the movies, but the prior one with Ashton Kutcher was a better film IMO.

Read the book it was based on and was shocked about how inaccurate the movie was. About the only thing that was factual was that Steve Jobs did work for Apple. Fassbinder's Steve came across as an Armani model of which Steve was not. The only saving grace was Kate Winslet. She stole the show.

First off, if you are going to make a movie that is NOT a biopic, and that relies on accounts of events that are NOT true, but rather are indicative of what might have happened or been said, then don't make the title of the project "Steve Jobs". Call it something else. That being said, the movie is extremely disappointing. The title character did amazing things in his, too short, lifetime. He was amazing because he saw the huge potential in transforming clunky giant computers like you'd see at Mission Control just before lift-off, into person-scaled electronic appliances that could facilitate human creativity in almost unimaginable ways. He imagined it and he made it happen, AND he started out IN A GARAGE! Add to that fact that he was adopted, that he dropped out of a small college where he studied calligraphy, that he was a hippie, that he eventually ended up being one of the most famous people of his era, and you have endless material for a book or a movie.Yet . . . what I watched in the theater this past weekend was a tiny snapshot of someone who was bitter and angry. Creative? Clever? Visionary? Nope . . . those traits, though apparent in non-fictional accounts of Jobs, didn't fit the narrative Aaron Sorkin decided to write. Fassbender was fine, Winslet was fine, Daniels was . . . fine. Everyone did fine work. Danny Boyle, even though he was forced to direct in a sort of a creative strait-jacket, also was fine. I have no problem with Sorkin creating characters in his work that convey personal inner-narratives or revealing aspects of the human condition. Many great films have gone into the father figure area: Santini, Corleone, even Vader! And Sorkin's track record certainly seems to indicate that he has a knack for dissecting the psychological landscapes of father figures and their influence on their sons. That's great, he should certainly explore that motif with gusto. But I can't help but feel that, in this case, he took advantage of an extremely well-known figure.

What a disappointment. If you enjoy watching an a*hole have lots of heated dialogue with individuals then you may like this. I was really looking forward to this movie based on my love of Apple, and the brilliance behind Apple, but this was truly disappointing. Lack of plot development, I guess I missed knowing ahead of time the movie is supposed to focus behind 3 product launches, but it made for lack of development in the movie.
Extremely well made technically. Extremely inaccurate. I hate to think most viewers of this fill will believe they've seen an at all accurate portrait of Steve.

What amazed me was how fast it went, and how it seemingly has three different plots going on that you never exactly see a resolution for. But, the dialogue is gripping, the performances Oscar worthy, and it always feels like it has a purpose and is progressing toward something. Great movie.
Incredibly brilliant. The combination of Boyle x Sorkin = masterpiece

After reading Steve Jobs by Walter Isaacson I had made some assumptions about the type of person he would be. I was totally blown away by the movie, he was much more complicated a person that I had imagined. I was also adequately aware of how much he changed the world, and what a devastating loss his death was. I loved it and would highly recommend it.

Short version: Steve Jobs is easily among the year's best films, period.Longer version: The mile-a-minute dialogue of Aaron Sorkin's screenplay rivals The Social Network for the best thing he's ever written, a reminder of just how freaking great a writer he is when he's restricted from diving into his TV work's more self-indulgent pitfalls (he really does seem best-suited to feature film scripts). The performances are uniformly fantastic, with Michael Fassbender and Kate Winslet as the Oscar-worthy standouts and Seth Rogen proving once and for all that he's more than "that stoner guy" with a turn that's equal parts funny, frustrated, bitter and soulful. Tying it all together is director Danny Boyle, lending a story that's otherwise an entirely dialogue-centric 3-act play a cavalcade of visual style and pulsing kinetic energy. Acolyte of the cult of Jobs or not, this is a hands-down absolute must-see that I'm already itching to see again and again.
Disappointing. This movie is based before 3 different conferences and 90% based on his daughter. The last movie and pirates of silicon valley were much better films.
Doesn't talk at all about the genius, but just focuses on certain dialects that happened behind the scenes of product launches. Snore zzzzzz

Steve Jobs is a film that builds emotion and momentum on interactions, rather than action, and whose script is as meticulous as the detail put into by its lead actor to portray the tech icon. The story is not about the products themselves, but the relationships. Fassbender delivers an exceptional performance and shines under Sorkin's screenplay, while Winslet and Daniels offer brilliant support as well. By the nature of its script, however, the first two acts, while building brilliantly, end abruptly. 9/10

Nearly all of this movie is arguing. We get the idea, Steve jobs was very bad at compromising and thought he was god. Sometimes he was and sometimes he wasn't. Nevertheless, there were several people sleeping and storing in the audience when I saw it tonight. "The Woz" describes him in the end as an asshole. You learn a lot about Jobs but I wouldn't recommend this unless you really like fighting.

What can I say. It is amazing that Danny Boyle and Aaron Sorkin can create such a dull, dead and uninteresting movie about such an an interesting person.There are so many things to dislike I hardly know where to begin. One of the most awful things was the overwrought and overbearing music. I literally put pieces of tissue in my ears during the loud and harsh music crescendos. I could not hear the actors screaming at each other (that is what it felt like...pure screaming).The other part that was tragically disappointing was the small limited area of his life the movie concentrated on. I was longing to see his genius as a product designer and visionary. The movie did not express the most fascinating part of this man.What a shame. I feel angry at the movies creators for missing a great opportunity to show what Steve Jobs was like as a person extraordinaire. I want Boyle and Sorkin to have to sit through the movie every day for the next 6 months so they can figure out all the ways the messed this movie up.

The fear with any biopic is that its resulting portrait will drown the subject's darkness in sappy sentimentality. Aaron Sorkin and Danny Boyle's overcast sketch of Apple's late co-founder overcompensates in the opposite direction. In the quest to show the tumultuous thunderstorms forever brewing inside a calculating, alienating tech wunderkind, the central character's unrelenting chill becomes both implausible and a detriment to a story that should have been a slam-dunk connection. Like the man who says he plays the orchestra, Steve Jobs is certain of its virtuosity, determined to stay on its dreary path at all costs. Michael Fassbender will net a best actor nomination, but the incomplete story and narrow, bleak lens limit his opportunities to shine the way he could have.It was impossible, as the final scene at the 1998 iMac launch faded to black, to ignore the protestations from Jobs' colleagues and associates who have decried the film's portrayal of him as inaccurate. Sorkin called the movie a painting, not a photograph. The problem: He and Boyle needed a Da Vinci, and they didn't create one.

I can't believe I just spent money on 2 hours and 2 minutes of Aaron Sorkin's genius envy. Wow, does Sorkin have self-esteem issues or what? The movie is basically non-stop arguing, thing is though, the words aren't really quotes from Jobs but rather fiction/fantasy rants invented by Sorkin. Not entertaining and the only thing I learned is that I will never pay to see another Sorkin movie. Sony REALLY dodged a bullet when it dropped the project.

Like a good Aaron Sorkin script, the movie is filled with snappy and wordy dialogue, but dang is it great dailogue. Michael Fassbender gives an Oscar-worthy performance as a man who was seen as a genius, but also seen as a jerk, which he is in this film. Whether or not these conversations actually took place doesn't change the fact that Danny Boyle's fast-paced direction showing three moments of Jobs' life is an interesting one. Even with all the talking, each act flies by. Kate Winslet, Jeff Daniels, Michael Stuhlbarg and Seth Rogan are all exceptional. Grade: A-

My wife and I were so excited to see this movie. We've been Apple fans since the 80s and have followed Steve Jobs' illustrious career very closely, as have so many others. We were so saddened by his untimely death and often have pondered what amazing things he might have done had he lived for another three decades as so many of us are lucky to do these days. Of course, I had known about his early years. When you are as famous as Steve Jobs is, when your products are so well-loved and ubiquitous, there aren't a whole lot of secrets about you after awhile. But I was looking forward to seeing his life, or at least a part of it dramatized.My wife and I walked out before the end. This movie is so unpleasant, so strangely myopic, especially when considering the complexity of the subject, so tedious, so over the top VERBAL (yes, we expect that from Sorkin, but he was, after all writing a film not about himself, but at Jobs, and as everyone knows because we've all seen the clips and the documentaries, Jobs was not like that). The movie was so narrowly imagined, and, may I emphasize imagined here because so many aspects of the film did not gel with facts that even older members of the public like myself, know to be true. I wanted to know where his other family was. His wife and his three kids. Why was there no mention of them at all if this was a movie about the man and his relationships. And if it was simply a movie about him and his daughter Lisa, then one has to consider that Lisa lived with the family throughout high school and part of eight grade if I recall. I read about the ending. IT MAKES NO SENSE! How could Steve and Lisa have a reconciliation back stage at a product launch when they were living together! ABSURD!. Shame on Sorkin. Shame on Rudin. Shame on Universal for promoting complete falsehoods under the name of a human being we all know so much about. Do you think we are idiots? I hope this movie flops.

The movie format is great. The story is both intriguing and interesting. Fastbender and Winslet played very solid rolls. The two hours goes by too quickly but the story ends in a place where you feel satisfied that you have had a glimpse into Jobs's life. After watching the movie, I read that much of the movie was more artistic interpretation that was based on facts. I would recommend this film. I am giving it 3.5 stars. I am not sure why I do not think it is a 4 star movie. Perhaps because I read all of the really positive reviews and my expectations were very high going into the movie. The movie does a nice job of showing Jobs as a person, a cult leader, a business leader and a technology pioneer. I found the relationship with his daughter and John Scully to be equally as fascinating for very different reasons. On the one hand, it was interesting to watch Job develop and to mature as a father and on the other hand it was interesting to see how Jobs and Scully interacted on many different levels. At times it was hard to figure out who was the mentor and who was the student between Jobs and Scully. The ending was fairly "Hollywood" without going over the top. You are left with the impression that Jobs has figured it out. "it" being his work and his relationship with his daughter Lisa.
Very intense, lots of yelling and bullying but it made us want to research Steve Jobs background and beyond this movie
Well acted, but it's a film more about the writer than the subject.
Same old Sorkin. Flashy but bears no resemblance to fact -- a disappointment.

I don't really care for Apple, but this a decent movie. While the plot basically just bounces between different presentations he was involved in, they managed to put the backstory throughout each of these. Seth Rogen as Wozniak was decent too but Fasbender was just a very good Jobs. Much better than Kutcher.

In this extremely intense film ( the audience MUST pay attention in order to keep up !!) Jobs is depicted as a genius visionary who was the ultimate at "playing the orchestra". He's also depicted (simultaneously) as a dictator who could push even fellow geniuses ( such as Steve Wozniak) up and above the breaking point. He's also having a complicated relationship (or lack or relationship) with his daughter and her mother who's depicted as someone unstable. There's a lot goin' on and I would have preferred a 3 hour film that shows most of his life, as it is, it starts in 1984 and ends in 1998. If you want more about Jobs read an accurate bio. I'm not sure, but it seems to me the negative parts of his personality were exaggerated here for dramatic effect, but the screenplay by Sorkin is still brilliant, and it's clear to me Michael Fassbender is one of the 5 greatest actors in the world today. His performance will blow your mind.

The movie should have been named, "Steve Jobs - Dramatic Backstage Moments".If you're expecting a biopic, based on Walter Isaacson's book with the same title you'll be very disappointed - despite the opening credits stating that it's based on that book.This film was a narrowly focused, tedious, verbose, showcase of screenwriter Aaron Sorkin's tremendous need to hear himself speak. And he got Boyle, Fassbender, and everyone else to buy into it. Yuck.The theme of the movie was how incredibly flawed and downright dark Jobs was towards his daughter. It's really, actually hard to watch.No scenes of Jobs' childhood, college years, home, wife, son, iPhone, illness - none of it. All we get is endless amounts of Sorkin's bloviating between Jobs and Hoffman. Not fun, not interesting, not informative - just a lot of the same.And we see no happy moments. Really, none. It gives new meaning to the word "film negative".There was much more to the man than this movie shows. It's a disservice.The Ashton Kutcher movie, "Jobs" is now considered with a new appreciation. Looking back, I actually really enjoyed it!p.s. Spoiler alert - and I put it at the bottom in the hope that I DO spoil it for you. It's worth spoiling. Save your time and go see "The Martian" again. smile emoticon

I say give Michael Fassbender the golden statue today because I can't see any actor (other than maybe DiCaprio) giving a better performance than him in Steve Jobs. The supporting cast are all great, Kate Winslet in particular and I loved the way Danny Boyle filmed the movie. The dialogue is sharp and quick, does it get a bit repetitive a couple of times? Yes. But it's a fascinating look at the genius that was Steve Jobs.

"Steve Jobs" is a tour de force, which showcases the talent involved at peak performance. Danny Boyle directs with ferocity a tenacious and engaging script penned by Aaron Sorkin. Michael Fassbender awes as Jobs in one of his most powerful performances yet, perfectly blending the man's egregious persona with his more intimate doubts and eccentric character. Other standout portrayals include Seth Rogen as Steve Wozniak, showing he has the talent outside of his stoner schtick, Kate Winslet as Joanna Hoffman, in one of her more engaging performances in years, and Jeff Daniels as John Scully, demonstrating once again why he is one of the more underrated actors working today. Overall, a towering film thats only flaw is its unfulfilling ending, but that's probably how Jobs would have wanted it; leave the audience clamoring for more. 4/5

Fantastic!!! Crisply directed and snappinglly written this movie is virtually all dialogue that takes place in 3 parts before the Launch of 3 different products. My favorite actor (tied with Tom Hardy) Michael FAssbender and my favorite Actress Kate Winslet (tied with Julianne Moore) give fantastic performances that should see them both attending a lot of awards shows this season. Seth Rogen Jef Daniels and Katherine Waterson are also notable. Probably not for evr4yone but perfect for me

In his biography on Apple Computer co-founder Steve Jobs, Walter Isaacson frequently gave accounts depicting Jobs as impervious to empathy. Isaacson correctly suggested that this characteristic could make Jobs intolerable to his subordinates, but aided his success in turning Apple from near insolvency to the most valued company in the world. In this dramatization, by writer Aaron Sorkin and director Danny Boyle, the filmmakers are committed to portraying Jobs as sympathetic by concocting a phony redemptive story thereby diminishing his achievements. It takes place during a series of important product launches during the ten years that included Jobs being terminated by Apple followed by his return to become CEO. Most of the action is set backstage at the San Francisco Symphony Hall, amidst squabbles between Jobs and his family plus associates. Boyle directs in the standard Sorkin walk and talk style with numerous Steadicam tracking shots, but the pacing lags at times and there are moments when the editing is distractingly disjointed. Sorkin is great at sophisticated repartee, but his depiction of the estranged relationship between Jobs and his daughter is overwrought psychobabble. When Jobs confides to his daughter that his haughtiness is the result of being 'poorly made,' the scene isn't affecting as intended it's just embarrassing. It's also disappointing there isn't a stronger sense given on what made Jobs and his products so popular and innovative. As Jobs, Michael Fassbender is grandiose, imperious, disparaging. He never goes soft even when the material does. Kate Winslet is compelling in an enhanced role as a marketing executive and forthright confidant to Jobs. Seth Rogen is quietly impressive as Steve Wozniak. With Jeff Daniels, Katherine Waterston, Michael Stuhlbarg.
Like a mix between The Social Network and Birdman, Steve Jobs is impeccably scripted and superbly acted. Talking has rarely been more riveting.
One of the best movies I have ever seen.

There's something to be said for a film without special effects, big set pieces, or action scenes, and still is captivating from beginning to end. Steve Jobs is one of the most important figures in our generation, if not the most. While I'm typing this review there's a commercial for the new IPhone 6S, the man's imprint is everywhere at all times. But to me he's always been a bit of a mystery. Everything from his relationship with his supposed daughter to the broken friendship and partnership between him and Wozniak has fascinated me. Although this film may not tell the whole story, it tells one hell of one. With the best screenplay of 2015 and tremendous performances all around, Steve Jobs is one of the best films of the year. With an incredible end product, it's hard to remember all the troubles this film had behind the scenes. With the shuffling of directors, lead actors, and even studios, for awhile it seemed unlikely this film was ever going to get made. Foe what it's worth, I would have loved to see what Christian Bale would have done with Jobs, but Fassbender proved to be a strong choice. He doesn't look much like Jobs at all, but he seemed to capture his mannerisms and his presence for this rendition of jobs. Credit should also be given to the terrific ensemble cast. Kate Winslet held the film together as much as her character did her Jobs himself. Seth Rogen, who wouldn't normally associate himself with dramatic roles, gives a Jonah Hill in Moneyball like performance. I don't know if it will get him an Oscar nomination, but I think he may deserve one. Someone who may actually get one is Jeff Daniels, who plays John Sculley. Both him and Rogen have demanding roles and scenes several times throughout the film, and they always rise to the occasion.But I think the hero of this film is the screenwriter Aaron Sorkin. The film is set up as 3 acts each right before an unveiling of one of Jobs' products. It's a structure that hasn't really been done before, but also proves to be very effective. It's jarring and even understandably annoying the first time they go to black as Jobs walks out on stage, but the material behind the stage is so interesting that you get used to it. The run-time is a brisk 120 minutes, but I could have watched 150 if they would have shown the presentations. Though we don't get a look into his products on the stage, we have youtube for that, we do get a new understanding of the man behind the products and it couldn't have been more fascinating. It's worth mentioning Danny Boyle's great work behind the camera as well, although I'm having a hard time dividing the credit between him and the brilliant screenplay of Sorkin. For nothing else, this film should be seen because of its sharp and intelligent dialogue and Oscar worthy performances.+Fassbender brings it+And so does everyone else in the cast+Give Sorkin the Oscar now+Boyle handles the structure well-Cut off some intriguing moments9.3/10
Not a bad movie by any means, but certainly not the best way to tell the story of Steve Jobs. We are yet to see the film that this story deserves.
Lil' bit slow. Damn.
Really disappointing. Was expecting something like Social Network. Ended up with un-ended talking and spoken exposition with the entire moving covering three not-so-interesting days in Job's life.

With a screenplay written by Aaron Sorkin, you really shouldn't be worried. Once again, he writes a tight, tense script, that highlights the most interesting moments in the life of the late "Steve Jobs." Choosing very carefully, this is a very well-crafted biopic in the strangest way. Michael Fassbender is terrific in the title role and Jeff Daniels, Kate Winslet, and Seth Rogen (surprisingly) play off him extremely well. This is a character study and nothing more. Unlike the film "The Social Network," which focussed on both the characters and the entire process of the creation of Facebook, "Steve Jobs" is even more dialogue driven, but it begins after Apple has been created. Danny Boyle definitely has his direction stamp on this one and it shines beautifully through the images on screen. Overall, "Steve Jobs" is a great ride for what it is, but nothing is all that exciting about it. I would give some nods to the writing and acting that this year's Oscars, but I think that is where the amazement ends. In the end, I had a great time with this film.
One can quibble about the historical inaccuracies, but this riveting, fast-moving, fast-talking film features spot-on performances from both Michael Fassbender and Kate Winslet.
Bunch of left wing garbage, it is.
As much about relationship and life choices as it is about Steve Jobs. The cast and direction are great but the writing is what I felt crackled and really shines up on the screen.

Great movie with phenomenal acting and writing, as well as direction and editing. To be honest, it is all great here and when it ended I almost wished it would continue. Jobs here is just so fascinating as a character study. The only mark against the film is that the jumps in time and the intense shifts can be a bit jarring, but I suppose that's in keeping with Jobs' personality here. Overall, it works well and is worth watching again. In my opinion, Kate Winslet deserves the Oscar for Best Supporting Actress in this film. My rating is 4-4.5, bumping it to 4.5 for excellence in nearly all categories.

There was so much hype about this movie, and I had such high hopes for this movie. So what happens? I walk out disappointed. First of all, I have no idea what was wrong with the Steve Jobs movie with Ashton Kutcher. Does the academy just pre-decide which actors and what movies will be nominated? Just as far as this movie goes, I thought it was going to focus more on the life of Steve Jobs. Instead, it more focused on Apple plunging at one point and then coming back as a successful company. Now, the last movie about Steve Jobs did not so much focus on the life story of Steve Jobs, but it showed how Apple got started. With this movie, I could not quite understand the storyline the makers of the movie had in mind. I cannot say that Michael Fassbender did a bad job in this movie, but I do not think that he was fit to play this role. I thought Ashton Kutcher did a better job. Kate Winslet did a pretty bad job in my opinion. Seth Rogen was fine, but I still saw him as a comedy in this movie. My point is that if you want me to give these actors a thumb up, they have to give me the willing suspension of disbelief. In other words, I do not want Michael Fassbender to try to play the role of Steve Jobs; I want to see him become the part like Bradley Cooper in American Sniper. All in all, I am not going to try to stop you from going to this movie because it might be up for a lot of awards. I just did not quite understand the big deal about this movie after I saw it.
not very good, focuses mostly on his product launches(mac and the next cube) and his crazy relationship with his daughter and her mom

There is no plot, the whole movie is word barf dialogue, and the annoyingly persistent focus of portraying him as a "skewed reality mad scientist genius" drove people mad enough to make them walk out of the theater. The point is driven home in the first 10 minutes but PAINFULLY dragged out over the entire 2 hours. Save you time and money.
I liked it. It has a weird ending, that if you don't follow the news, you would never know what happened. But, it was an enjoyable movie.

Good acting for the most part. Several annoying and unfortunate fashion and style gaffes. Despite these negatives, you kind of have to see this story as it is "The Origin of Species" of the virtual world we live in today.

Its not so much of a biography as it is a story about 3 of his product launches. Its interesting how they left out Pixar. I was a bit disappointed. If you are an Apple fan or a tech fan, you may be interested.
I'll just ditto Linda Cook"s review...if you're okay with dialogue, this one's for you.

Talk about a missed mark and a giant disappointment. I don't understand why Skorkin had to dream up so much fiction around Jobs' personal relationships and work. He took what should and could have been a fascinating depiction of one of the most interesting people of our time and instead made up a story that is almost unrecognizable from what happened in real life. Why? I'm so confused by this movie and the other reviews. The advertising and movie descriptions imply that it is a movie about Steve Jobs' life but that is actually quite a stretch. The acting was good (loved the cast) but otherwise I feel duped in having spent what we spent on movie tickets.

This was a terrific film with outstanding performances by Fassbender, Winslet and Daniels - actually everyone in the cast should be commended. Sorkin's writing was, as always, spot on, summing up a complicated, deeply flawed genius in a 2-hour tour-de-force. The movie portrayed a guy whom you hated and admired at the same time. And they gave props to Alan Turing, the 1940's genius upon whose shoulders the whole computer revolution stands. At the end, I had tears in my eyes.

Almost everyone is aware of the influence that Apple and Steve Jobs has had on each of our lives -- as computers replaced typewriters and data-sharing blossomed into personal communications. Jobs' vision of meshed computers and ordinary phones gave us encyclopedic iPhones on-the-go and removed distance from the human interaction equation.Steve Jobs' revolutionary smart phones, tablets and laptops have changed our lives, and the way the world revolves, for the better. "Steve Jobs" the movie, however, only skims the surface of his significant life-changing contributions to your life and mine. It focuses less on one of the most forward-thinking and innovative souls in history, and more on the troubled perfectionist who had difficulty acknowledging--and even working with--others. It's fascinating to contemplate that the man credited with bringing people and businesses closer together on the planet, had a reputation for repelling others and not sharing credit.In one of 2015's strongest leading performances on film, Michael Fassbender effortlessly plays the narcissistic Silicon Valley high-tech pace-setter. As Jobs, Fassbender's fast-paced movements and quick tongue unveil a cold-hearted, ruthless friend and boss at a trio of historic product launches spotlighted in the film.It's at these dark, mostly anger-filled global announcements where viewers find themselves behind-the-scenes, standing between Steve Jobs and those at the receiving end of his bitterness and frustrations. The first twenty minutes of "Steve Jobs" is mind-blowing and quickly offers us an uneasy glimpse into the man behind the gadgets we use today.A rapid-fire script by proven screenwriter Aaron Sorkin, along with extended scenes using numerous characters, both underscore this story's troublesome look inside a creative mind that harbors serious personal flaws. After this stark revelation in "Steve Jobs" is apparent, the remaining part of the film becomes redundant and overwhelmingly anti-climactic.A sensational supporting cast, including notable performances by Seth Rogan and Kate Winslet, upgrade the operating system of Fassbender and Sorkin. Individually, they should provide enough terabyte memory to give "Steve Jobs" serious end-of-the-year award consideration. However, its stale plot and abrupt ending shouts continuous "Downloading..." to movie-goers, who find themselves waiting for the story to move further along.There's no argument that Steve Jobs was the conductor of the microcomputer orchestra. By "inventing the future" the self-admiring Apple leader changed the world. "Steve Jobs" takes the work he started in his parent's garage with computer-programming geek Steven Woznicak (Rogan), and launches those products under a barrage of tirades and ego stroking. The longer Jobs' personal faults are displayed in this film, the more viewers are left just wanting to see the next product rollout. A sad consequence for one of the most visionary minds of our lifetime.Grade: C+

Opportunistic, simplistic, BULLSHIT in the highest degree. Staging melodramatic scenes packing in everyone Steve Jobs knew, just so they had the requisite conflict to sell a scene. Too bad these folks wanted to trade in on the brand known as Steve Jobs to sell tickets. If you couldn't do him justice, you should have left him alone.

Not only an in-depth study of a man whose life was riddled with complex relationships, but it's a film that maintains your interest and elevates your curiosity about the subject as the minutes pass. Perfectly written, acted, and directed. Solid film that may not find itself winning too many awards, but should certainly be nominated for a myriad of categories, including music, editing, and cinematography.
I think I learned a lot about Steve Jobs from this movie, but I have no idea what the f_ _ _ I just saw. I've seen something, but, in plot-wise, I don't remember anything about this movie.
The writing is great, the acting is great, the story is good.I certainly recommend it. I love the writer (Aaron Sorkin) and Geoff Daniels. I'd watch anything with this combination. Go see it!
An abstract, if not poignant film with a core theme of family and rejection.

This movie got me realizing my regret for getting the Mac Plus first over the Apple II as my first computer, but truth or not, it's Fassbender's portrayal of Jobs that is a sure win! Kate Winslet delivers some of the best lines in this film and these three areas in Jobs' life featured is well worth the watch! I was already wanting to see another film that can focus on the latter years until his untimely death, but my Apple Watch interrupted my thoughts while watching this gem of a movie! His relationship with his daughter is gripping to the point to really gain even more insight on how he was! Definitely worth a second time watch too!
Wildly overrated. I knew it was inaccurate going in, but I thought it at least be interesting. Definitely not worth seeing in a theater and I'm not so sure about video either.

The biggest takeaway from this movie is that although Jobs was a shrewdly brilliant businessman, he also was a flawed individual who often behaved like a complete turd to those within his inner circle. Structuring the film in vignettes centered on three major releases during his lifespan is a novel idea which allows for many interactions to be covered within a brief window of time, but sometimes it feels too hectic since so much is being balanced at once. Top notch acting from Fassbender, who completely disappears into the role.

While there is greatness in this movie - performances, directing and movie structure in particular -�and successfully avoids the pitfalls of being just Apple fanboy fodder, as a whole it ends up being just a good movie that teases with overall greatness and comes nowhere near being "insanely great." Michael Fassbender turns in an engrossing and deft performance as Steve, capturing Steve's drive for excellence in the computing world and his stumbling faults as a father and friend in the human world. Unfortunately the character lacks some of the soul of Steve -�his quirkiness and hippiness that also defined him and made his drive for excellence more than just excellence for the sake of excellence. It's this facet of Steve that, during product launches, I feel gave him the near giddiness of a 10-year-old on Christmas morning. It's this facet of Steve that is missing from this movie that would have humanized him just enough, challenged Fassbender just enough, to elevate the movie to greatness.

'Steve Jobs' feels more like Aaron Sorkin's movie than Danny Boyle's. Sorkin's now trademark style is the screenwriting equivalent of a sustained machine-gun shootout, and this time the rounds are pumped out without pause for two hours. The relentless script packs a tremendous amount of wit, intelligence and intensity and sets up a dream role for an actor. There aren't too many A-listers who could have pulled it off, but thank the stars Michael Fassbender was available. As may be expected, there have been complaints of inaccuracy, but never mind the reality distortion filter - this is an entrancing film.
Really disappointing outside of Fassbender who is spectacular. Sorkin and Boyle just don't mix very well.

Smart, well acted, and occasionally humorous, Steve Jobs brings a strong biographical drama to life, thanks to incredible performances by Michael Fassbender, Seth Rogen, Jeff Daniels, and so on, plus some masterful direction by Danny Boyle, I can simply say it's one of his best films since Trainspotting, 28 Days Later, Slumdog Millionaire, and 127 Hours!

As movies go this is a great film. As biopics go not so great. Aaron Sorkin & Danny Boyle made a great movie, but the inaccuracies of Steve Jobs' life are outstanding. I've read the book, studied the man, & heard the experts. This seem nothing like the complete story. This movie must be in it's own reality distortion field. Great acting by Michael Fassbender, Kate Winslet, & company. Recommended to see, but not everyone was into Steve Jobs and will like what they see.

This movie was more of a biopic of Steve Jobs than 'Jobs' was. 'Jobs' honestly should've been called 'Apple' because that is what it was about...Apple. 'Steve Jobs' focused more on relationships and developed, and it worked well. The acting by every cast member was fantastic. Although 'Jobs' wasn't as good as the 2015 version, there were certain parts in that film that I feel could've been used. Watch both movies, and you'll agree with me.

This is a truly electric and energized movie with a strong ensemble performance reading Aaron Sorkin's poetry to us audience members. Sorkin is our Shakespeare with really intelligent dialogue to a challenging degree with how he likes his screenplays' pacing to be. The screenplay is well formatted into a 3 act structure that would make a brilliant stage play especially with the intensity of some of the tension between 3 different story conflicts happening on the same stage between Fassbender and Rogan then to Ortiz and then to Winslet. I really liked those aspects of the movie even if they do seem a bit contrive to fit the structure. The only areas where the screenplay doesn't work is that it leaves Jobs as a human a bit empty. With a structure like this and only brief flashbacks that last less then a minute it is hard to truly humanize Jobs progression as a human over time, it all has to happen in one location in each section of the movie. The ending also felt a bit out of place with how sentimental it got with an awkward tonally misplaced song use in the climax that could have been better if it was just a moment in the score. The score is also brilliant and props to the hair department of this movie for the drastic changes in looks some of the characters go through. Fassbender is great as Jobs, though blinking more could have helped him seem like a human and not a robot like he played in Prometheus, and he has this kinetic energy to play ball with any actor that comes in his path. He bounces off each actor with crisp timing even though sometimes he'll have false moments of changing his attitude over something he was persistently against and in a matter of one long argument giving up like he was always on the fence about it like actions involving his ex wife and daughter in terms of money but that was in part of a script flaw as well but Fassbender never really sold me on those moments where he was quick to take back something like with holding buying a house for his ex wife. Speaking of her, Katherine Waterston really impressed me as Jobs' ex wife. After her bland breakout in Inherent Vice, it was very refreshing to see that she actually has emotions as an actress. I've been very mixed with Kate Winslet over her two decade long screen work with more positivity towards her first half of work but this was a nice return to form for her. Though her accent was all over the place by the end of the movie especially in the 3rd part, she really held her own in the chaos that Fassbender was always in a shuffle with. She really gives one of her strongest performances since 2006's Little Children. Seth Rogan gave a really nice supporting performance, although he seemed to age backwards in time, having surprisingly greatchemistry with Fassbender. Rogan has the dramatic chops that he gave a little preview with 2011's 50/50. One of my favorite TV actors of this decade Jeff Daniels doesn't lose any of his Sorkin rhythm from The Newsroom to this. He is a bit underused but the whole sequence in the 2nd part of the movie between Fassbender and Daniels is breathtaking. There were moments in this movie that made me feel the same way with Mad Max Fury Road earlier this year. I had to take a large sigh of relief because I felt like I just went through an adrenalin rush with this movie being the dialogue rather than car chases in Mad Max. I also really liked Michael Stuhlbarg that gives his best performance since 2009's A Serious Man. He deserves more great work like this and I think he has a big part in Trumbo in a few weeks so I am looking forward to that. I also loved all the actresses that played Jobs' "daughter" as he denies throughout the movie especially the oldest in the last section. Though Sorkin's dialogue and the pacing and the look at someone most of us have admired but is taken in a more off-putting tone from the movie, this does feel like The Social Network in ways which makes you confused and have to remind yourself Danny Boyle is behind the camera and not David Fincher. Boyle seems very distant not allowing his fingerprints too much on the filming itself and doing as Jobs says in the movie conducting the orchestra that is made up of Sorkin, the cast, and the camera. If you are not an Aaron Sorkin fan, your mind will not change with this movie because this is definitely more like The Social Network and A Few Good Men rather than something a bit more restraint like Moneyball or Charlie Wilson's War. With the film's pacing, I was astounded when I looked at my clock real quick to see an hour passed by when it felt like 20 minutes went by. I actually think the movie could have been longer maybe delving into the conference before the iPhone was announced or adding some moments of really delving into the human side of Jobs rather than the take no prisoners work ethic he had. There is a documentary out this year on Jobs that I hear is a good counterpart to this that can fill in some of the parts that leave you empty here so I will definitely check that out once it is available on DVD or Netflix. I also want to give a shout out to the unique way the movie is shot. The 1984 and parts of 88 look very grainy and make you feel like you are watching an 80's movie but when you get to 98 you feel like you are watching a more modern movie with how crisp and clean it looks. So overall, it is a well constructed movie that is very dependent on every aspect working well with each other and it does for the most part and will leave you breathless after many moments. This is one to go into with an empty bladder because missing one beat of this train ride could throw you off its tracks.
Nothing but nonstop dialogue for two hours and it feels like an action movie. Super intense. Not really a biopic. I loved it. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

Unbelievable script. It does confirm what we have all known, Steve Jobs the man was a jerk as a father, employer, and man. Expecting us to follow a movie that everything in his life happens and is resolved at the launch of a failed product.
Steve Jobs is made up of electric scenes, but it never finds something to satisfyingly tie it all together.

Incredibly directed and beautifully shot. The acting was amazing. Michael Fassbender nailed the less likable side of Jobs and Seth Rogen was surprisingly talented at capturing Woz's discomfort and dislike.

Only 1 star and that's for Jeff Daniels. Many hardworking talented actors but Aaron Sorkin's confusing, pretentious, fast talking but not believable story. Wished I listened to the critics I admire. Barely could stand the last act of this 3 part snoozer.

Solid biopic that features wonderful acting & innovative storytelling but plays to fast & loose with recent history. Fassbender is superb as Jobs, and while he doesn't quite look like him (at least in his younger days) he captures Jobs's brilliance & arrogance that somehow morphed into a charisma that made you like him even at his worst. The rest of the catch is equally excellent, with Winslet almost unrecognizable as Jobs's long suffering assistant while Rogen shows his dramatic chops portraying Wozniak as someone who loves his friend but just wishes he wasn't such a jerk. Behind the camera, Danny Boyle makes solid use of the story structure, anchoring around the three major launch events of Jobs's career (the Macintosh, NEXT, & iMac), trying to compact his epic life in a two hour movie. For the most part, it works, with subtle graphics & interesting techniques, such as using a different style of camera for each time period. The main problem is Sorkin's script, which does have some brilliant dialogue (of course) along with hints at future inventions (a scene over a wrist-watch by Jobs & Wozniak not only illustrates the differences between the two but hints at the IWatch). However, using Jobs's relationship with his daughter Lisa seems shoehorned in, as his wife & other children are not even mentioned, while his sister, Mona Simpson, gets only a passing comment. It does score points by not always portraying Jobs in a pleasant light and shows his relationship with his daughter wasn't perfect, even in the end. Overall, a solid film that does get to the essence of Jobs but not quite accurate & fully formed.

Found myself falling asleep during the first half of the movie. General synopsis: Steve Jobs has a brilliant mind for marketing computers, but behind closed doors, he is an egotistical asshole who doesn't give his colleagues their due; Secondly, he initially refuses to acknowledge that his daughter is really his, but as she gets older, he wants to reconcile with her and prove to her that he loves her. The End. Boring movie. Two hours of my life I will never get back (and I like both Aaron Sorkin and Michael Fassbender)

I come from thre era of well acted movies, long scenes, real emotion. on the Beach, HighNoon, 12 Angry Men, etc. I saw "steve Jobs" today. powerful, emotional and I hope historically correct. Michael Fassbender, Kate Winslet, all terrific. Ionly knew the cover stories of the Apple II and the Newton and the iMac but this filled in blanks. Seth Rogen was the conflicted Wazniak. His soliloquy was powerful. I'm not a great reviewer but Iknow what I like an this was worth the money.
If you enjoy seeing people yell and argue for two hours, you'll enjoy this movie.
Engrossing, yet never spellbinding, the film teeters in attempting to understanding it's complex figure, yet ultimately settles on a story of a father reconciling with an estranged daughter.
Wow... That was bad.
Fabulous.Fast-paced, intellectual, moving entertainment.Acting, writing, and directing; all top notch.God, I absolutely love this movie.

Similar to the other Steve Jobs biopic, Danny Boyle/Aaron Sorkin interpretation also paints a nice picture on the eccentric co-founder of Apple by having the same intensely-moving approach to drama The Social Network was best known for, and adding an impressive approach to three-act structure through authentic 16mm-digital visuals to go along with Michael Fassbender's character development. A-
Seth Rogen, F*ck You!
It was a very well directed and acted movie, but left me cold and unsatisfied. Re-enforced why I've never liked Apple products... Jobs was an arrogant prick

You can certainly argue that the scope of this film is too narrow to do Jobs justice. And this is certainly not going to be the definiteve Steve Jobs film. Yet this is a wonderfull, compelling film which essentially examines a slice of Mr. Jobs' career and family, and it does so in a masterful fashion.Sorkin had a vision and he delivered. Fassbender was spot on and Winslet was superb. Worth seeing.
It's far from smooth sailing but it's still one of those must see films and Aaron Sorkin's screenplay is genius.

Artful ad elegant with masterful work from Fassbender, Winslet, Stuhlburg, and Seth Rogen. While I am sure some will complain about its repetition with showing the behind-the-scenes of a different launch, the performances are electrifying, Sorkin's dialogue snappier than ever before, and all of it feels like watching a great three-act play come to life. Much like "THE SOCIAL NETWORK", Steve Jobs is an innovator and pioneer but also a giant asshole to friends, loved ones, and colleagues. Through the course of the film, his dynasty and digital revolution are brought to the epicenter and tested, and he must come to terms with while he may be a so-called genius in reinventing the way we use computers and digital devices--- as a person, he wasn't the most pleasant or decent human being. In some ways, how Sorkin and Boyle craft it, it's like a modern day "CITIZEN KANE." We see the rise, fall, and rise again of Jobs. I highly recommend it even if you're not the biggest Mac and Apple fan.

What a mess. I was hoping this movie would provide some insights into why Jobs made Apple so successful, but it wasn't even close. This was more about Jobs' demons in his personal relationships with people. It showed really nothing why Jobs wanted a corporate suit like John Sculley to run Apple. There were some flashbacks about Jobs vision for changing the world, but that's nothing new. This was just such a disappointment when there was so much meat left on the bone. It was shallow and Jobs came off as condescending to everyone else at Apple. No one would be inspired by such an asshat; they would just leave. Jobs almost killed Apple with his unrealistic demands and meddling in technical decisions. The actors pulled off good performances, but with such lousy execution and a childish script that's all they could do.

Erudite look for the brain behind the Apple computer; defeats its own investigation into what constitutes genius and success with a tepid theme about fatherhood and responsibility. Obsolete, out of the box dialogue dominates the conversation, repeating endlessly stuff we already know. Should be called A GEEK'S LIFE.

WORDMAN: Or (The Unexpected Virtue of Being An Asshole) - My Review of STEVE JOBS (3 1/2 Stars)Aaron Sorkin must have shit a brick when BIRDMAN came out, because STEVE JOBS, as audaciously entertaining as it can be at times, is THE SAME DAMN MOVIE! Told in three parts, all located backstage at significant product launch events in the Apple co-founder's career, the important people in his life congregate for their turn to yell at this difficult, arrogant, strategic, cunning, neglectful, impossible man. No, it's not told in a single shot and no, Michael Fassbender, who excels at letting us into the energetic mind of Jobs, doesn't levitate or sprout wings, but the dissection of a man as told by his coterie remains the same. Pairing Sorkin's wall-to-wall dialogue with the kinetic, visionary director, Danny Boyle, sounds great on paper. While written like a stage play, Boyle's hiring brought with it the possibility of infusing it with his boundless energy. Unfortunately, this is Sorkin's film all the way, and Boyle's stamp can barely be seen. In the trailer, there's a shot of the back of Jobs' head as he waits in front of a door, a pause, and then he bursts through. It's what I was hoping for from Boyle, this tension between stillness and action, but those moments are so few and far between. There's a beautiful wide shot in a hallway with a projected image that feels tacked on as a heavy-handed afterthought. A not-so-subtle rainstorm takes over the background of a key boardroom scene. It feels like Boyle is doing everything he can to get an "ahem" in there, but it's a losing battle against Sorkin's vision. It's not that the film is lousy. Far from it. It's just a one-sided marriage. This is tricky, adult, smart, vibrant storytelling, albeit the very type that won an Oscar a year ago, and wholly the work of its writer. In addition to the electric Fassbender, Kate Winslet, as Jobs' Polish Marketing Exec Joanna Hoffman, who can go toe-to-toe with him more than anyone else, gives a furious, committed performance. The heart and soul of the film, however, belongs to Seth Rogen as Jobs' former partner, Steve Wozniak. Rogen finds the humanity in the man who would eventually become overshadowed by the CEO in the glasses, turtleneck and Mom Jeans. Michael Stulhbarg, so great in A SERIOUS MAN, plays Andy Herzfeld , Apple's Chief Developer, with great underdog bravado, firing snappy one-liners back at Jobs with great skill. Same goes for Jeff Daniels as John Sculley, a one-time Apple CEO, who has to bring the hammer down on Jobs on more than one occasion. Katherine Waterston, so good in INHERENT VICE, proves that performance was no fluke, with her turn as Jobs' ex-girlfriend and impoverished welfare mother. They have a daughter together, Lisa, and Jobs' inability to recognize her as such is, along with Wozniak's storyline, the emotional arc of the film. STEVE JOBS shines a light on a man's fight to excel in business and innovation while his fundamental decency erodes. The baby steps Jobs takes towards his own humanity are presented in true fashion to its subject, without a shred of overt sentimentality. Instead, we're left with a warts-and-all portrait of a megalomaniac struggling with such things as gratitude and selflessness. Had it not been done before and so recently, I would be jumping up and down more for this film. Sure, it's less a biopic and more of a compact look at a man trying to get his way during the key moments in his professional career. I appreciate that it doesn't look at his entire life, intending to get at his essence instead. Sorkin refuses to dumb down his non-stop dialogue and characters, forcing the audience to stay alert. Cinematographer Alwin H. K�chler, who also shot Boyle's SUNSHINE, works overtime to make these backstage rooms sing, but there's no disguising the Broadway play just itching to get out from under the movie treatment. A film about a marketing master who, along with the real geniuses, has changed how the world interacts, is worthy. I was hoping, however, for a little more innovation, instead of the very "Sorkin-y" walk and talk on display. Still, I highly recommend STEVE JOBS, because movies about smart people almost never happen anymore. Jobs seemed to know that the only way to realize his vision was to be a complete jerk. Perhaps Boyle, who is known for being a truly nice guy, could have put his foot down and inserted his voice a little more, then STEVE JOBS could have been a brittle masterpiece. We'll have to settle for really, really good instead, and that's something Jobs would have never done.

As written by the brilliant Aaron Sorkin and directed by the equally brilliant Danny Boyle, Steve Jobs is a biopic that fires on all cylinders- it's a passionately made, rigorously entertaining, and deceptively subtle film that takes an intriguing and introspective look at a controversial public figure without sugarcoating his legacy. Jobs himself is brought to life by an explosive, career-defining performance from Michael Fassbender

Great script by Aaron Sorkin(esp. the dialogue), great performance by Michael Fassbender and Jeff Daniels, and Danny Boyle's directing is also average. Overall, it's good movie, but I still think that "The Social Network" is better.

Enjoyed the film however, all the drama happening right before each launch event kinda took me out of the film. Made me feel like I was watching is play. I would have rather seen a more traditional linear dramatization of his life. The cast was really great!
This is an Oscar-worthy screenplay, with great performances all around, especially from Fassbender.

A pretty big showing of the Old Geezers Who Go To The Matinee Alone for this bio of the Apple creator. I never like Apple computers or Steve Jobs, who seemed to be to be 10% and 90% ego and the movie did little to do that. I am writing this on a MacPro, so times do change. The movie focuses on Jobs rise and repeated falls with computers and his highly charged relationship with his daughter. Michael Fassbender is in every scene and the movie is held up, way up, by his performance. Kate Winslet, his amazing co-star compared the role to Hamlet; not sure it's quiet that, but it is pretty good. I found this a remarkably will made movie as expected from Director Danny Boyle. Go if you get the chance, I'm sure you will like it.

This movie takes a different approach and looks at the personal relationships and struggles of Steve Jobs. Always difficult to guess what is going on in someones head or heart, but for me the insight was helpful and inspiring.

If you want to see great acting, check out this movie. Written by my favorite Hollywood writer Aaron Sorkin (West Wing, Social Network, Moneyball) this movie will demand you keep up with its fast paced dialogue. Not sure how much of the story is true (as with Social Network) but for a 2 hour movie of mostly two characters arguing, it builds up drama quite nicely. I would've liked to have seen more computer talk with a concentration on Apple's most recent products, and less on family squibbling, but the movie works. Seth Rogen has some good scenes and weak scenes, Jeff Daniels impresses as usual, and Kate Winslet steals the show as a Polish marketing mastermind. Then there is Michael Fassbender (Magneto) who will threaten for the Oscar. I would RECOMMEND, but it can wait for DVD release.

Michael Fassbender's acting is outstanding and worthy of an academy award. If you didn't read the biography of Job's, you will probably enjoy the movie. The movie covers 3 times in his life. It doesn't mention he has a wife and family, that he has cancer and that he had wonderful adoptive parents. Aaron Sorkin has beefed up the role of Joanna Hoffman (Kate Winslet) considerably. She was a minor character in the book. Way too much time was devoted to abandoned daughter Lisa.
"Steve Jobs" is NOT factually accurate but it captures the essence of who Steve was and what he stood for. It's also weird watching a very Hollywood version of a man I grew up watching.

I go to 1 new movie a week and 2015 as been a veryforgettable year for movies...so far. Looking out onthe horizon for the balance of 2015, there are somepossible special movies but nothing I'm over the topexcited about.The advance "buzz" the new film "Steve Jobs" includedsome pretty eye catching adjectives and phrases. Thisdidn't overly impress me in that most anything associatedwith Apple and the late Steve Jobs always had the bestmarketing brilliance.Still, I wanted to see this true story on this amazing yetpolarizing business talent. At the end of the day, his productson his watched transformed generations with the personal/microcomputing/entertainment vision. Jobs had an unparallelledability to create brilliantly performing products in enticing "configurations" that the consumer desired. Hencethe success of his brand and products is world renown.So lets cut to the movie which from start to finish acutelyshowcases Jobs brilliance combined with his arrogance and acerbic nature. This man, played to an Academy Award level by Michael Fassbender, grabs us from the moment his face hits the screenand doesn't let go. The movie is built around several of Job'smajor product releases (Lisa, Next and IMac) and the near rockconcert level fervor of the techno community.Doesn't sound overly sexy or engaging, but folks it is quintessential excellent movie making and watching. Directedby Danny Boyle (Slumdog Millionaire, 127 hours and more) and the screen play byAaron Sorkin (Social Network, Moneyball and much more), thismovie grabs you and holds you throughout.This movie isn't like watching a trainwreck to see/hear someuber-cold thing Jobs will say or do to his work colleagues orfamily. Because the "tough stuff" is balanced with businessbrilliance. That's what makes this movie so good and makespersonalities like a Steve Job so engaging.The guy is virtually friend and relationshipless (includinghis daughter Lisa) and his life seems held together in allareas by long time assistant (and business talent in herown right), Joanna Hoffman played incredibly by Kate Winslet.She sincerely deserves an Oscar nomination here.She spends her life putting out Jobs's fires while nudginghim on a path forward (professionally and personally) whilehis seems to unabashed to blowing up that journey with averbal bomb.This was a TERRIFIC movie on so many levels and too, I'm sure,because many of us lived thru and were impacted by theJobs/products/Apple era (pro or con).This was top shelf movie which will do very well in the boxoffice. Not a blockbuster but really well done, tight movieproduction that grabs you and doesn't let go....courtesy ofmesmerizing and complex Steve Jobs. Very, very well done film.

The acting and dialogue are great-lots of nice quotables. I also like the way it's shot. One unfortunate thing is it stops too soon. It doesn't go nearly far enough into Jobs's/Apple's timeline. I found this to be extremely disappointing. But for a bio pic this is a good movie, and it's interesting to learn some of the details about Apple-to get Jobs's point of view on things.

When you watch the movie ?Steve Jobs? (R, 2:02), you are witnessing genius. That?s a word that shouldn?t be used lightly, but here it fits ? on multiple levels. The subject of this biopic is basically universally considered a genius for bringing personal computing into the homes of average people and changing our lives in other ways as well. But Jobs himself is only the most obvious example of genius in this particular motion picture. Screenwriter Aaron Sorkin, who also wrote the TV shows ?The West Wing? and ?The Newsroom? and films including ?A Few Good Men?, ?The Social Network? and ?Moneyball?, once again shows his own genius for writing dialog and constructing scenes in which interactions among people become high drama. If anything, in the script for this film, he tops himself by giving the story a unique presentation. Add all that to the inspired direction of Oscar winner Danny Boyle (who won for directing 2007?s Best Picture Oscar Winner ?Slumdog Millionaire?), plus brilliant acting, and you have a film with genius to spare. Genius, however, doesn?t necessarily equal perfection.Steve Jobs, visionary genius that he was, was far from perfect ? as an individual or a businessman. He had a daughter with college girlfriend Chrisann Brennan, but denied paternity for years. Even after he accepted Lisa Brennan as his daughter, he had almost as much trouble relating to her as he did relating to others in his life. Think of a derogatory term, anatomical or otherwise, that people apply to males they don?t like, and Steve Jobs has been called it. Loyal to only a very few, no one was safe from Jobs? rudeness, often unreasonable demands or contempt when they disagreed with him. And let?s not forget that, at Apple, he developed the Macintosh, which flopped. He got fired from Apple, founded NeXT Computer and developed the NeXT Box computer, which also flopped. Even geniuses make mistakes, but what recommends them as geniuses, in the 20/20 hindsight of history, are the final results and long-term impact of their accomplishments. Steve Jobs scores undeniably high marks in those areas. The triumphs and tragedies, successes and failures, mistakes and mayhem in Steve Jobs? life, as described above, are all part of the film ?Steve Jobs?, but are encapsulated in a unique way. The movie takes place immediately before three crucial product launches staged in large auditoriums. The settings are the unveiling of the Macintosh in 1984, the NeXT Box in 1988 and the iMac in 1998. In each case, Jobs (played by Michael Fassbender), with his long-suffering PR manager, Joanna Hoffman (Kate Winslet), at his side, he interacts with Chrisann (Katherine Waterston) and their daughter, Lisa (played at five, ten and nineteen by Perla Haney-Jardine, Ripley Sobo, and Makenzie Moss) as well as his partner in founding Apple, Steve Wozniak (Seth Rogen), Macintosh designer, Andy Hertzfeld (Michael Stuhlbarg) and Apple CEO, John Sculley (Jeff Daniels) plus others, through the various stages of warmth, apathy and conflict between them and Jobs at these specific moments in time. The movie gives us these three main scenes, adds a few brief flashback scenes to illustrate other important moments in Jobs? professional life, and that?s basically the movie. If that doesn?t sound interesting, it?s most likely due to my lack of genius in communicating the true genius of Sorkin, Boyle and many others associated with this film. ?Steve Jobs? is a terrific cinematic experience. Although Sorkin?s writing fabricates conversations for dramatic purposes, many of the people portrayed in the film have admitted that those conversations reflect events and feelings that were valid at those moments, and the script is vintage Sorkin. He has a particular genius for telling a story mainly through conversations which he manages to make dramatic, insightful and humorous ? and this may be his best work ever. Boyle?s direction, plus some creative and skillful editing, bring the script to life wonderfully and Boyle gets consistently remarkable work from his actors in roles large and small. The acting is of such high quality across the board, that it?s very tough to single out just one or two actors for special praise amid a long list of award-worthy performances. A few moments in the film do feel like they?re walking a line between believable and unrealistic, but those moments are few and far between. Like the real Steve Jobs? accomplishments, the accomplishment that is the film ?Steve Jobs? isn?t perfect, but at least in my MacBook, they both earn the label of genius. ?A?
See this film before the Oscar nominations make it more difficult to get a ticket!

The thing that makes Apple products so attractive is its simplicity and efficiency. This movie is a far contrast from however from that, but the movie show's through it's unique three part structure, the behind the scenes life of Steve Jobs. His life was far from simple and efficient. His products are everything that he is not and what he wishes he were. Through the vision of Danny Boyle (Director of Slumdog Millionaire and 127 Hours), he gets the chance to show that Jobs was always inventing things within things in his life. Boyle shows how complex Jobs is and behind the fancy tech, OS, and hardware; there was love within his iconic products. Academy Award winner, Aaron Sorkin, wrote the screenplay. While it isn't his best work, he manages to be like the Apple company. Have a weak start, but finish strong. Ironically, Slumdog Millionaire has the same feeling. First hour of that movie sucked, but the second hour is just mesmerizing.

When I first heard about the structure of the new Steve Jobs film I was hesitant. The film is broken into three main parts. The first being the launch of the Mac. The second being the launch of the Next computer. The third being the launch of the iMac. I was hesitant because I felt like the film should tell more and I thought that it might get boring just showing these events for 2 hours. I'm glad to say that I was completely wrong. I was also hesitant about Michael Fassbender playing Jobs. Not because he isn't a great actor because he is but because he looks nothing like Steve Jobs. Fassbender becomes Jobs in this film. I wouldn't want to see anyone else playing this iconic figure.Steve Jobs is hands down the best film i've seen so far this year. It's spectacular and sure to get plenty of Oscar nominations. The three nominations I'm sure of are Best Actor (Michael Fassbender), Best Supporting Actress (Kate Winslet), and Best Adapted Screenplay (Aaron Sorkin). Steve Jobs will at least WIN Best Adapted Screenplay. I also wouldn't be surprised if Danny Boyle got a Directing nomination as well as Supporting Actor noms for both Seth Rogen and Jeff Daniels who were tremendous in this film.There is so much tension between characters in this film that really make most of the scenes. The dialogue is brilliant. The acting is award worthy. I've never seen Seth Rogen give a better performance and Daniels really made up for that spit in the face film that I won't name here. Kate Winslet was really great as well. Her character gave a lot of heart to the film. The film did such a great story telling Jobs life within these three events. We didn't need a whole bio picture. These events told so much. Would I have liked to see more with these film-makers/actors involved? Yes. But it's not necessary. The relationship between Jobs and his daughter across this film is amazing to watch and my favorite part of the film. Overall, I would definitely recommend checking this film out as soon as possible.

I never expected the film biography of Steve Jobs to be pure dramatic theater.BirdmanFollows one director backstage three days before opening night of his Broadway play. Steve JobsFollows one director backstage before three key product launches of his computers.It is very fitting that the movie's approach to the biography genre is also the movie's core of Steve Jobs: think differently.Think theater.A literary orchestra to represent his life.AKA many people talking. Very eloquent people.*Warning: Spoilers BelowSteve Jobs in all his (difficult) glory clashes with representative figures in his life: his daughter, daughter's mother, and work-wife; Apple partner, boss, and programmer.We are swept up in the backstage energy of pre-launch secrets and product issues, honesty spawning hysteria, friends emerging as frenemies,strategy for justice or revenge, ongoing ideology versus money, and at the heart of it all, deep beneath an icy, scathing surface: Steve's passion and his daughter.Three pivotal debuts of Steve Jobs as a creatorare brought to life by raw, brutally honest performances. The movie's orchestra of human nature plays no false notes.We empathize with everyone, even going so far as to dive into Steve's mind, achieved by seamless editing of memories that affect his present thoughts, particularly potent of father figure Sculley, and of his daughter Lisa.Conventional Computing Biographies condense a whole lifetime into a series of significant events. Inevitably, writers rewrite history and some parts are glossed over, left out, simplified, and customized to many, many different versions.iBiopic by Aaron Sorkin has a simple structure and intricate core. We glimpse Steve Jobs three times, he's living his life in the moment, and we're along for the dialogue ride.
Brilliant. I'm going to need more Aaron Sorkin-Danny Boyle collaborations in my life, I think. And Michael Fassbender was amazing.
I felt I was watching others play a steve jobs trivia game.

Steve Jobs is an incredible film and I'm not just saying that because I own a MacBook Pro and an iPhone 6+.To think Michael Fassbender might not get an Oscar for this performance is absolutely criminal.Kate Winslet was equal to The Fass Master, she gives an outstanding performance as well.All the performances were nothing short of outstanding. The back and forth between characters in this movie left me in awe. Seriously jaw dropping stuff. Aaron Sorkin absolutely killed it with the screenplay! It's easily my favorite screenplay of 2015. I also LOVED the score. It had this old school retro beat to it and it fit the film perfectly.This movie is more so a drama than a biopic. This isn't a Steve Jobs life story. The movie focuses on the behind the scenes of 3 major press conferences Steve Jobs took part in. I really liked this aspect of the movie because the movie starts off with a bang and it doesn't let up. There's really no down time. If you're looking for an in-depth film about the life of Steve Jobs, I think a documentary would be a better fit. I myself plan on checking out a more in-depth documentary because now I'm really interested about learning more about Jobs.If the Oscar committee snubs this movie, I'm going to be legitimately pissed off. Steve Jobs is by far one of 2015's best films as well as Danny Boyle's best film. Such a captivating film overall. I loved every second of it.
Biography through conversation. Brilliant on all levels.
Incredibly structured so that you get all of Steve Jobs' life, his companies, projects, and co-workers, all from three hours of his life.

It was electric from start to finish thanks to Aaron Sorkin's script. The main cast was great in it but especially Michael Stuhlbarg who needs more love and Sarah Snook who needs to be in more things. The movie acts less like a theatrical bio-pic and more like a stage play which is a much better route to take it. I do think it'll win best screenplay because it does the heavy lifting.

Completely opposite from the former film and one of the best movies of the year.
The Steve Jobs story that we should have gotten 3 years ago. It is everything you want to know and need to know about Steve Jobs.

"The minute I heard that this movie was made in a way similar to that of a play, Had a feeling this would be right up my alley. Amazing performances, a script that actually makes just dialogue exciting, beautifully structured, The film is ingenious. Probably not for everyone. But none the less, an achievement."

I thought this movie was really bad, and I wouldn't pay to see it if I was you. Think about waiting till it comes out on popcorn time or redbox instead. You can thank me later...During the entire movie Jobs is portrayed as a arrogant prick, and although he was at certain times in real life, I felt that they spent way too much effort making sure you know that he is indeed a prick. The whole script is jobs arguing with someone. If I wanted to see two people nagging at each other for two hours I would have gone to my in-laws for dinner. I read the Steve Jobs biography and I feel that the whole movie is a dishonest picture of the real Steve Jobs. He was indeed a complicated man, but I don't see anything worthy of an award or your money here. The whole movie takes place behind the curtains before Apple's product releases over the course of his career. It seems like we never leave the building, and all you want is a breath of fresh air outside, but every scene is jobs and another associate engaged in a bitter argument in a hall or dressing room. Instead of being inspired when I left the theater I felt exhausted after having to listen to that movies dialog. I'm not exaggerating here, from the moment the movie starts to the very end it is a constant argument between jobs and another.

i'm not an Apple "cultist." Every PC I've ever used has been a Windows machine. I am, in fact, the only Android user in my household.:) I'm also not familiar with the factual details of Steve Jobs' life, so I can't really evaluate the film on that basis, though there are those who have found significant differences between what is presented here and what was documented elsewhere. That said, as a piece of FILMMAKING, this is very good. Michael Fassbender creates a credible character as "Steve Jobs." Kate Winslet as Jobs' "work wife," is also very good as are Seth Rogen as Steve Wozniak and Jeff Daniels as John Scully. I wouldn't be surprised to know that we learn more about Aaron Sorkin than we do about any of the "real people" depicted on screen.
Loved this movie! I was totally engaged the whole two hours. Having been a part of the tech industry for the last 40 years, I remember all that this movie portrays.

Let's be honest. To truly tell the story of Steve Jobs it will take HBO to create a miniseries. It has not, and cannot be done with a two hour movie. And this one is just a mess.This movie depicts only several moments from Steve's life. Everything else we learn about Steve is done through fabricated conversations backstage at product launches. For the casual viewer this may be acceptable and they will feel like they learned a lot about Jobs. But for somebody who know the history of Steve and Apple there are no new revelations. Nor is it visually entertaining because we know these conversations are merely the creations in Aaron Sorkin's head. None of them actually happened.Hopefully somebody will eventually take the time to write an accurate script based on his biography and make a 10 hour miniseries that truly details the genius of how he changed multiple industries and the madness and chaos he caused with the people around him to do so. But trying to cram a wild and complicated life into two hours is a futile attempt and this movie points that out on so many levels.This movie ONLY worth seeing for the acting and the dialog, which are both great. But without actually depicting any real events from Steve's life, it's not insanely great.

+With a definite Best Actor Oscar nomination for Michael Fassbender, Best Supporting actress nomination for Kate Winslet and probable nominations for screenwriter Aaron Sorkin and director Danny Boyle along with Jeff Daniels and/or Seth Rogen for Best Supporting Actor I wish I could say "Steve Jobs" is a 'must see' movie but the most I can say is the fast smart dialogue while walking fast, a trademark of Sorkin's, along with director Boyle's kinetic use of the camera, aided by the soundtrack of Daniel Pemberton, add up to an interesting movie. Sorkin has written a 3 act screenplay, each act revolving around a creation by Jobs such as the Apple II, the NeXT and the iMac computers, while Doyle films the first act in 16mm film, the second in 35mm and digital for the third act.It is generally known and accepted that Steve Jobs was a cold, dictating boss who never gave credit to anyone keeping it all for himself, gave more love to his technological creations than to any human being, never treated anyone around him fairly, was an impossible perfectionist, always composed, cool and in charge, comparing himself to G-d, Julius Caesar and seen as a bully but even those who hated him acknowledged him as a visionary.The fact that he was adopted and given back after a month to be adopted again, being brought up as a Catholic, refused to acknowledge the birth of his own daughter until she was in her teens and his long time, non-sexual, working relationship with Joanna Hoffman (Winslet) who was one of the few who could and did stand up to him, are never dealt with in depth which may have helped explaining the man himself. We learn little about the man himself which is a big failure of the film.There is no faulting of the actors from the three, Makenzie Moss, Ripley Sobo and Perla Haney-Jardine who play the daughter at different stages, Katherine Waterston who plays the mother, Mac collaborator Andy Hertzfeld, played by Michael Stuhlbarg, to all the supporting and bit players. Daniels takes his character from "The Newsroom" a step higher!Fassbender IS Steve Jobs even though he may not look like him to start with eventually he is the man you have seen on large stages introducing his products. He handles the pacing of Sorkin's words and Doyle's camera along with the anger he feels not knowing how to deal with feelings. The relationship between Winslet and Fassbender though her loyalty to him and why he would listen to her and not others is never explained but because of the actors you accept that it is just what it appears.For excellent acting, snappy, sharp dialogue and above average unobtrusive directing plus award conversations "Steve Jobs" is a film to see.

A fascinating angle at flaws both human and technical, amongst blurred family lines and operating systems. Sorkin eschews a complete biography for an urgent feel piece - what it would be like to work with the man, the myth, and the father. The performances, exchanges symbolically employ just enough of a stage feel, and all the elements rise to the subject matter. As mentioned Fassbender and Winslet are at the top of their game. For Jobs, the clock was ironically ticking, the third time was the charm, and his orchestra didn't disappoint us. Same can be said for this very specific program.
While the film was not based on Walter Isaacson's wonderful book, the movie has significant pieces of Jobs' career with a stellar cast. Fassbender was magnificent as SJ.
