If you go into this movie expecting a film about Steve Jobs numerous achievements in the world of technology, this isn't quite that movie, this is more a movie about Steve Jobs the father. The film is anchored by terrific acting, character development, and pacing, which help make the film quite enjoyable. The story revolves not around Jobs entire life, but 3 separate events, and the minutia of the rest of his life, the structure to clarify is similar to last years Birdman, and the film is very different from 2013's Jobs. The acting in Steve Jobs is superb, perhaps most impressive of all is Kate Winslet's performance, as through most of the movie she transformed into her character, as did Michael Fassbender. Michael Fassbender will surely receive an Oscar nomination for this performance, as he literally transforms before the audience's eyes. Jeff Daniels is as was expected reliable and equally as great, but may get drowned out by the other performances. The other notable performance was that of Seth Rogen, who made a turn for the dramatic, and hit a home-run, completely selling himself as Steve Wozniak. The plot of the film is character driven, and in many ways the greatest strength of the film is the character development, especially that of Steve Jobs. Boyle and Fassbender perfectly capture the psychotic, frenetic, genius, bipolar attitude of Steve Jobs, while also showing a great character arch, as he evolves as a person. The film could have been a little too melodramatic, but the direction and acting save it. The acting and character development also help form the surprisingly frenetic pacing of the film. The film is paced like a day in a beehive, where every character is running in circles, never taking a moment to breath. On top of all of the acting, character development, and pacing the film is also funny, at times touching, and different from the other Jobs films. The film represents an award caliber performance by screenwriter Aaron Sorkin, director Danny Boyle, and most of the cast. The only complaint may be the film's computer and business lingo is occasionally, not often but occasionally, too confusing for a non computer whiz to understand. Using great character development, acting, and pacing Steve Jobs is another great entry in Danny Boyle's ever impressive filmography.
The liberal messiah.

After the debacle that was the Ashton Kusthor Jobs a few years ago, Danny Boyles Steve Jobs hits it out of the park focusing on a through line of three product launches and the turmoil surrounding each one both professional and personal that helps shape Apple as a company as well as Jobs as a person. The acting as one might expect is first rate from Fassbender in the titular role, Winslet as his right hand strong arming the people and media around him to keep them from penetrating his protective shell, Rogen as Woz the best friend technician and Jeff Daniels as the wooed Pepsi CEO who eventually ousted Jobs after a disasturous product launch in the first third of the film when Jobs vision proved too early. The writing yet again is rat a tat by Sorkin who seems to have a knack for this larger than live tech figures, having been previously with the Social Network, and the direction for Boyle is sure handed and well crafted using three different film stocks to mark the three periods and use of a heightened reality in places to mark the passion of the art and style that the Apple founder had for his image and products. One of the stronger entries to fall prestige season and sure to garner some attention for its writing and acting.

Also, Seth Rogen give his best performance in his career in this movie. When Mr. Rogen is on the screen, he will blow you right away." The directing by Danny Boyle and screenplay by Aaron Sorkin is so well directed and written so well. The cinematography is good. The score is good. Finally, the effects are fine. "I'm raving that "Steve Jobs" is a the best movie of the year. A must see movie!"

Most of the time through this movie I kept thinking, "there isn't really a plot here." I think the actors did their roles well, and the story had great dialog and was able to create an impressive amount of emotion without bringing much to the table. But that was also the hindrance. More than once I felt myself asking myself what the point of the story was.From everything I have read about Jobs, he was very much like this. An *beep* who demanded people do and achieve more out of tools he had no idea how to use. Than when they were able to accomplish it, he just acted like they owed him great thanks for pushing them.It wasn't until the end that we finally got some relief as all the people he was always a dick to finally came back at him. Which is really all the movie is. It is people firing back at him at launch presentations because they all knew in the end what Jobs never did (in the movie). And that was created anything. He may in fact have "played the orchestra" and that does matter (think of the President, they don't do much of the work, but they drive the bus). Obviously his marketing and artistic talent show through, but like many bosses, he never actually worked on the nuts and bolts, and never knew what they were asking for.It felt very similar to The Social Network as portraying the founder (co-founders) of massive companies that broke the mold as complete *beep* I was actually waiting for an epilogue seen where Jobs would be dying in his bed of cancer and the word "KARMA" would flash on the screen. What was truly annoying was when at the end, when for 3 minutes he acts like a caring father, and suddenly everything is all right.I guess he gets points for admitting he is a flawed human being, but like with many other lines spoken in this movie, I wonder if they are accurate at all.

Steve Jobs was an enigma of a man; I don't think we can draw exact conclusions to who Jobs was or his exact motivations regarding his family and his business. Apple impacted the world in so many different ways, some for worse or better for the computing world, yet the man behind is so vastly different from anyone involved with computers from that time. Was he nothing more than an intelligent businessman taking advantage of the home computer world or was he a genuine innovator in how home computers should be despite his own lack of involvement regarding the actual development of the computers. Steve Jobs (the film) works with whatever it can to give us the best possible image of the man, the film doesn't exactly claim to know all the answers, but it gives us an intelligent look into Jobs' world. Sorkin returns to writing autobiographical films in ways that no one else is currently doing. The screenplay of the film is both it's most fascinating and possibly flawed. The structure which follows through on the three biggest press conferences in Jobs' life is fascinating to see play out. On one hand this limits the film form to explore Jobs' life outside, but then again Jobs was all about his work wasn't he? Danny Boyle here seems to be channeling his strengths and manages to work out some of the flaws he's presented over the years. Once again he has a fantastic time with his cast, he manages to encapsulate Sorkin's style as best as possible (though not as well as someone like Fincher); Boyle manages to work his best gift of making the ordinary seem grand. It's perfect for the structure of the film and perfect for Boyle. It's almost pointless to talk about the acting as it's as good as you may expect. Fassbender, Winslet, Rogen, and Daniels all are outstanding and easily could be up for Oscar Nods. Fassbender fully encapsulates the strange nature and almost lighting fast speed of Jobs' brain as well his megalomania and capacity for caring. The mighty Kate Winslet returns with one of her best performances in a while as Jobs' smart-talking, intelligent, practical Joanna Hoffman, the more humane counter to Fassbender's more universal prattling protagonist. Rogen turns in a relatively short, but emotional performance as Woz which is sure to win the hearts of the audience and give the comedic actor some long due acting credit. Daniels is also in a short but sweet role as the former CEO of Apple who's inability to adapt to the times ultimately leads to something of an undeserving downfall. Overall though, Steve Jobs greatest asset is this blend that is both fantastic to watch but at the same time, lacking in something. Unlike something like The Social Network, which both encapsulates it's main subject as well as his creation, Steve Jobs isn't quite as deft as it's hand reaches out but doesn't grab everything. I still feel like I'm missing chunks of the important part of Steve Jobs (the man) despite knowing so much, I don't feel I exactly know enough to even draw a conclusion exactly. The film itself doesn't feel as intelligent to follow Jobs so we don't get the same fantastic feeling of understanding in Sorkin's previous modern Bio-Pic. As is though, Steve Jobs is still a very good film, not exactly great, but as far as the films pushing for major Oscar campaigns this year, it still will likely be better than most films coming up along with Fassbender's performance which will undoubtedly earn him a nomination and hopefully a win (because I'm sorry, DiCaprio doesn't deserve squat)

Michael Fassbinder is a much more credible Steve Jobs than Ashton Kutcher was in the same role. It is interesting to see how the character evolves over the years and how his relationships mature. More of an 8.5 than a 9, but this a fascinating film featuring very strong acting.The film has a very interesting structure. It's divided into 3 segments, each one being a behind the scenes launch of a product Steve Jobs was involved with. The first is in 1984 with the launch of the Macintosh, the second in 1988 with the launch of the Next, and the final one in 1988 with the launch of the iMac. While the film isn't shot in one continuous shot, it does evoke similar feelings to last year's Best Picture winner: Birdman. For the most part, the framing device works. Each segment is clearly different from the ones before it and each one offers fascinating insights into the characters.Speaking of the characters, the acting in this film is phenomenal across the board. Michael Fassbender is perfect as Jobs, creating a wonderful portrait of the biggest asshole around, yet also bringing out the genius (often insufferable) of Jobs as well. The scenes of him with his wife and daughter are truly fascinating as is his relationship with them, which seems both cold and caring at the same time.Kate Winslet is the heart of the film, playing Jobs' PR person at each event. Her accent (She's playing a Pole) is fine, but her interactions with Jobs are what truly make her stand out. Winslet should be netting her seventh Oscar nod for this. She's the anti-Jobs in every sense of the word and she and Fassbender play off each other beautifully.The next two actors to be mentioned should also merit serious awards consideration: Jeff Daniels and Seth Rogen. Yes, really. Rogen delivers an Oscar worthy performance as Steve Wozniak, whose constant desire for Jobs to mention the Apple II just feels more and more hopeless over the passing years. Now for Jeff Daniels as Apple's CEO before Jobs, he's incredible. Most of Daniels standout moments come in the second segment, the launch of the Next. Daniels' best scene is one where he and Jobs discuss why Jobs was forced out of Apple in the first place and Daniels nails every second of it as he and Fassbender go at each other with what can only be described as "verbal machine gun fire". Both He and Rogen nail their Oscar clips.The film features some beautiful cinematography, amazing editing (each segment feels so seamless, but this is Danny Boyle. He's pretty good at that), and some really nice sets. It's well worth a look and it is without question one of the most fantastically acted films of the year with an equally fantastic script to boot.

Films often vary the truth from what the historic facts were. But, if this movie is any indication of who Steve Jobs was as a person, then he is a total jerk. I've said time and time again that it is hard for me to watch a film whose protagonist is extremely dislikable, in my own opinion of course. One of the reasons why I don't like Pitch Perfect very much. But what made this film stand out was the outstanding performances and all-around great effort by the filmmakers. The screenplay was tight with some great dialogue and the directing was really well done too. But by far the best part of this film was the scene in which Michael Fassbender and Jeff Daniels argue about their real intentions at Apple. It's extremely intense even though it's just two people shouting at each other. The filmmakers make it seem more like a fast-paced gun battle then two people arguing. This film was really well-made and won't be surprised at all if I see this receive many nominations at the Oscars.

Quite good. I've not seen the other documentaries or films (Ashton Kutcher and Josh Gad, really?) so I can't compare it to any of them, but as a stand alone film this was quite well done. Each of the three acts is set on a different product launch ceremonies - the original Macintosh, the NeXT, and finally the iMac, with only brief flashbacks to other settings - but strangely enough the products only serve as a backdrop to his relationship with Wosniak, Sculley, and a lesser extent to Hertzfeld, but mostly on his relationship with Lisa. Quite good casting for her part, as the three actresses playing her really do similar enough that I never had to question who it was. Keeping the film centered on those product launches was a great idea, as it gives the film a focus while advancing the story throughout the years. The acting is great, especially Fassbender who nicely straddles the thin line necessary to portray a sympathetic jerk. Rogan might be the weak link, but even then that's only because I was very conscious it was him, as he's otherwise fine. It's certainly an interesting take on the person, and I'd give it a recommendation.

Awful and not enjoyable, If you like a traditional Oscar nominated movie like The Social Network, Titanic, Avatar, Boyhood, The Theory of Everything, or just pick any from the list. What I mean is a balanced movie with complex characters that you can relate to and an exciting and interesting plot.Great, If you're a movie critic type person, who loves character studies of madmen or very depressing movies just because of good acting. People that knew Steve Jobs witnessed Steve creating a Reality Distortion Field.I think that is what the movie should be titled. Watching Steve's reality distortion field, and this movie, is witnessing a version of reality where only Steve's version of reality exists. No matter how much evidence there is that something is not real, to Steve it is real.We see this in the most in Steve's view of the Mac, at the 1984 launch event and in Steve's belief that his daughter Lisa, is not his daughter throughout the movie.The question is do great visionaries and interesting movie characters have to be A-Holes because the people around them don't see the world that they do?This movie believes they do. It is not a balanced look at Steve like you get in Walter Isaacson's book, but a very one dimensional character study without humanity.

5/5 A burst of creative energy as well as a meaningful take on our relationship to technology and the complex figure behind it all. The screenplay, acting, direction, score, and editing are all orchestrated to perfection, and make Steve Jobs one of the year's very best films. Aaron Sorkin's script takes us backstage before three major product launches in Steve Jobs' career. The unique experience of the film revolves around this unconventional approach and Sorkin's witty, nonstop dialogue. The film forces you to remain upright and attentive as you try to absorb the densely packed dialogue, but this doesn't feel like a chore; it's more like a privilege. This is because the dialogue is genius, filled with lines so insightful and clever you'll take them for granted as they constantly zoom by. Sorkin will deserve the Oscar when he wins.Of course, the dialogue isn't much without great delivery, and the cast more than delivers. Leading the ensemble cast is Michael Fassbender, whose Steve Jobs unrelentingly manipulates the reality around him to fit the illusion that he's in command of his own world. He does this with distant emotional suppression and a harsh, cold exterior. His genius is there as well, and because of this, we can see how his egoism has gotten him so far, despite the poor way he treats others. Fassbender shows us all of this through his performance, avoiding the classification of simply being a "dick". His performance is far too complex for that, and he'll deserve the Oscar when he wins. Each scene is a sort of duel between Jobs and another character. Each character helps to bring about a different part of Jobs and each appears in each of the film's three parts either through working with him or by visiting him. Of course, this isn't likely the way things played out in reality, but Sorkin isn't trying to hide that. The way that the conflicts between the many characters played out were fantastic, with each player getting their own intense climax. Appearing most often among these supporting players is Kate Winslet, who makes it believable that her character can stand up to Jobs all the time, able to keep up with him through subtle understanding and care. Seth Rogen is excellent as well, proving himself to be a promising dramatic actor. I loved Michael Stahlberg's performance and Jeff Daniels was effective even if he mostly met expectations from the roles he's been doing recently. Katherine Waterson was great as well, going up against Fassbender with fierce sarcasm. Each of these actors gets at least one moment to shine, and boy do they shine when it's their turn in the spotlight. But possibly the most important character is Steve Jobs' daughter, played by three amazing actresses. The younger two convey an aching longing for a father figure when they're around the neglectful Jobs, and the oldest is a more mature version, understanding her father's flaws through the hole he's left in her life. Jobs' daughter is the emotional center of the film, and this center really is emotional at times. We can see how Jobs' neglect is suppressed and that it represents his biggest flaw. Jobs is unable to acknowledge mankind for its shared beauty, instead using his life to selfishly regain a lack of control that he feels as a result of his adoption as a child. The film expresses this theme not only through Jobs' character, but through the products he made. "A computer is not a painting," Wozniak constantly says to Steve, though which he traditionally replies, "fuck you." Jobs initially wanted to remove all compatibility options from the computer because of this viewpoint because he fails to understand technology and the human race as a collaborative effort. Although Jobs succeeded in many ways through his arrogance, the film argues that letting others in can lead to even greater accomplishments. Danny Boyle's typical visual extravagance is unleashed here at times, but he can be effectively restrained as well. He is great at capturing the hyper pacing of the digital age, making the film relevant by making Jobs feel like he's the very center of the technological revolution. Boyle takes scenes of pure dialogue and amps them up to create some seriously thrilling sequences. Some shots from the film are quite flashy and delicious, so creative compositionally that they should be placed in film textbooks. It would be wrong not to credit the editing and cinematography for much of this as well.Daniel Pemberton's score is one of the year's finest. His pulsating, bouncy electronics keep a rhythmic pace to the film that is effectively modern, and the more orchestrated tracks levitate scenes, making them feel virtuosic. A lot of people may feel that the redemptive ending of the film is odd, but in understanding how clearly fictionalized this film is, I didn't mind and thought the end really added to the film.Absolutely every aspect of this film makes for extremely entertaining cinema in a totally unique way. I enjoyed the film immensely both times I watched it, experiencing at once a great character study, an insightful look at our relationship with technology, and a moving drama. This is a must-see, folks.
"Steve Jobs" | C+ | Great acting, great writing but this repetitive drama is like watching your favorite one-hour TV series three times in a row. Ugh!

Has Aaron Sorkin ever written a bad screenplay/script? It is outstanding. The way they set up the movie in 3 scenes taking place right before product launches was brilliant. Definitely an Oscar worthy screenplay and performance by Michael Fassbender.

Steve Jobs by way of Aaron Sorkin. Michael Fassbender does a really good job. Kate Winslet, Seth Rogen and Jeff Daniels great to watch too...okay, maybe not Seth Rogen so much. Much like the Social Network, it isn't exactly flattering to its subject, but it still manages to make him more interesting than I ever thought he was in life.

A tour de force! Sorkin's script combined with Boyle's directing results in a film that soars from beginning to end as if played by an "orchestra". The best performances I've seen in 2015, nominated-worthy performances from Fassbender, Winslet, Rogan and Daniels. Do. Not. Miss. This.
Good character study, but Steve Jobs was known to have a violent temper. Not shown. And I really want to see his triumph through the iPod, iPhone, iPad years. And that wasn't in the movie.

I saw this one on a whim last night and I'm really glad I did. I was expecting another generic, yet well done, biopic. Obviously, this exceeded my expectations by tenfold. The three act play setup is wonderful. Instead of another generic biopic, you get a snapshot of a man at three very important stages of his life. Then, centering those stages in the minutes before a product launch is genius. It keeps the stakes high the entire time. Aaron Sorkin definitely hit a home run with this one. You also can't beat the cast of this movie. Michael Fassbender is more than worth the price of the ticket. But having Kate Winslet, Seth Rogan, and Jeff Daniels around doesn't hurt either. Fassbender is brilliant. We already knew he would be, but it doesn't hurt to reiterate it. It was a really honest portrayal, no sugar coating. We saw the great side of Jobs and also the side of him that was, to put it bluntly, an asshole. Then, keep it going with it being beautifully shot, even including the integration of some projections, and you have a movie that will be remembered for quite some time.

With all biases aside, I was amazed by this film...the acting was great, the screenplay and direction were genius...this is probably the first dialogue-driven drama that I've seen that could possibly be considered an action film of sorts just by its pace and voracity.
Horrible. So bad in so many ways. I really sorry for the talented actors that had to try to make a movie out of a script that was so awful. It is also a shame because the book was so good.

Steve Jobs on the other hand is yet another Sorkin masterpiece. Him and Danny Boyle combine to give us behind the curtain story of the man behind Apple. This film doesn't shy from showing both the good and the bad sides of Steve Jobs, and that's one of the key factors why it is such a compelling film to watch.Michael Fassbender may not look like the man, but he absolutely crushes it. There's an Oscar nomination waiting for him, but his supporting cast also is terrific, Winslet, Rogen and Jeff Daniels in particular.

I was really excited to see Steve Jobs. Aaron Sorkin is one of my favourite writers, and I love Danny Boyle and Michael Fassbender. I was also interested to see if Steve Jobs could finally be a good story for a film. Well, I can safely say that Steve Jobs is hands down one of the best films I've seen all year.The acting all around is astounding. I bought Fassbender as Jobs. His accent was spot-on and he really portrayed the man how he was: an asshole. I'm expecting a Best Actor nomination, and maybe even a win! Seth Rogan and Kate Winslet were both amazing as well. Steve Jobs has one of the best screenplays I've seen in years. Aaron Sorkin wrote yet another absorbing script with some of the most quotable dialogue I've EVER seen. There's a monologue from Woz that is utterly fantastic. There is very little action in Steve Jobs, but the captivating dialogue is constantly entertaining and interesting.Danny Boyle directed this film beautifully. It is split into a very unique three-act structure and it works amazingly. It is also very well edited, had great cinematography and has a fantastic musical score. The costume design, makeup and characters are also excellent.My only minor flaw with Steve Jobs is that there are occasionally pacing issues. It's barely noticeable, though.Overall, Steve Jobs is one of the best written and acted films to come out in 2015. See it ASAP!RATING: 9.75/10

Slow starting - Good characters and acting but the storyline just wasn't there - Just mainly a portrait of a detached man with a total lack of empathy - A poor look at the mans life - felt like it was a screenplay based on psych notes

Everything, including the performances, writing, style, editing and energy, is perfect in Steve Jobs, a breathtaking piece that charges forward with such flair, pushing the boundaries of the biopic genre

Not to mention, the title character is shown in such an unlikeable manor a majority of the time that you question why he gained such an acclaimed legacy to begin with. 3.5/5

Une l�g�re d�ception (� cause du r�al et de la musique) mais le cast est �videmment brillant et Sorkin (plus que Boyle) offre une magnifique pi�ce en 3 actes qui au lieu de se passer sur la sc�ne, au contraire se passe en coulisses, litt�ralement.

Steve Jobs (the movie), not the person (or is it?) is the new biopic directed by Danny Boyle, written by Aaron Sorkin and stars Michael Fassbender as the titular Apple Mogul Steve Jobs. Kate Winslet, Seth Rogen and Jeff Daniels are also a part of the cast as Joanna Hoffman, Steve Wozniak and John Sculley respectively. It follows the life of Steve Jobs around three major product launches in 1984, 1988 and 1998.If anyone was wanting a movie about the Apple company, then you'll be quite disappointed, but then again you would also be the one at fault for watching a movie called Steve Jobs and wanting more Apple. The first thing that you realize is the writing of the film and how inherently "Aaron Sorkin" it is. You may have become desensitized to the very "talky" way that Aaron Sorkin writes because of "The Newsroom", but for those who haven't watched the TV show, the sharp dialogue would be very noticeable with loads of walk and talk in true Sorkin esque fashion. This in combination with Danny Boyle's sharp direction results in a movie that rattles along towards its 122 min run time.The star of the film however, is Michael Fassbender in this neurotic portrayal of Steve Jobs. This performance would come as a surprise, not because of Fassbender (who is undoubtedly a great actor), but for those who actually were not aware of Job's personality of being a total ass to anyone he had an encounter with (which I did not know). This includes family, close workers and even friends. The story is revolving around Job's denial of him fathering a daughter and ultimately shows how that relationship is resolved over a 14 year period. The other supporting performances are absolutely great. Kate Winslet ever so good in another dramatic role who really is the only character that is able to sort of reign in Jobs. Seth Rogen was the surprise as Woz who was able to break out of his comedic shell and really held his own in his dramatic role. Jeff Daniels is once again in full Will McAvoy form from "The Newsroom" and that has everything to do with being around another Aaron Sorkin script and having three years of practice on how to deliver Sorkin's lines. This film is all about the performance of Michael Fassbender, who is sure to get a Best Actor nomination from the Academy, but it has a lot to do with the direction and the script of the movie. The plot does become repetitive within the three time points where you can sort of guess how each specific third of the movie will move along. However, the relationships between the characters and the dialogue (mostly due to Sorkin) are great, but it is a mish mash of three points put together and doesn't really become rounded by the end. Steve Jobs gets a grade of B+

So let me start off by saying, Steve Jobs is a film that I'm actually excited to talk about! So I'll start off by talking about the unique narrative. Steve Jobs is set behind the scenes at three different product launches set in 1984, 1988, and 1998 basically playing like three short films. Each shot differently with 16mm, 35mm, and digital. Michael Fassbender gives an incredible and iconic performance as Steve Jobs! On the surface he may not look much like Jobs, but the way he embodies the character and makes you feel every type of emotion for him, you no longer see Fassbender on screen, but Jobs himself! The acting in this film is flawless! Kate Winslet electrifies and her chemistry with Fassbender is something special! Seth Rogen gives his best performance as Steve Wozniak who is at times uplifting while also downright heartbreaking, and Jeff Daniels really stole the show for me! Daniels lights up the screen with an energy and bravado that I was not expecting at all! The screenplay written by Aaron Sorkin is no doubt the real star of this film and unexpectedly so. An oscar nom seems like a lock at this point. Director Danny Boyle crafts this film in such a way that is unique and really unlike anything you've seen before! Everything from the editing, cinematography, and score are all pitch perfect! Although not the biopic some would expect or want for that matter, Steve Jobs features oscar caliber performances from Michael Fassbender, Jeff Daniels, Seth Rogen, the entire cast really, amazing screenwriting by Aaron Sorkin, and unique directing from Danny Boyle, and is in my opinion, the best film of 2015!! Check it out when opens everywhere October 23rd! 5 stars out of 5
Brilliantly acted but painful if you don't like constant conflict and lots of flawed character

Aaron Sorkin�has made a career writing�clever scripts in which characters speak brilliantly conceived (if unrealistically articulate) lines of dialogue in well-structured dramas. Think�"A Few Good Men," "The American President" (which led directly to the 7-season television series�"The West Wing") and�"The Social Network." That last one is a perfect model for�"Steve Jobs," since it concerns a man deemed both an irrefutable genius and problematic human being. Sorkin got the equation just right there, showing us the virtues and vices of Mark Zuckerberg�in a world that, though clearly a dramatist's construct, felt as if it got the essence of the story right ... or at the very least made it interesting. Director David Fincher ("Gone Girl") moved things along briskly, and a good time was had by all (well, maybe not by Zuckerberg). Unfortunately, in Sorkin's new script about another flawed technology pioneer, the construct overshadows the story, and we are left wondering why, as represented by this movie, anyone would want to make a movie about Jobs.Divided into three distinct acts,�"Steve Jobs" is a triptych aiming for a�Hieronymus Bosch�take on morality that ends up, instead, as a Margaret Keane air-brushed "big eyes" portrait: poster art, in other words, instead of grand painting. There's no shame in superficiality when that is your intention - some of my favorite movies are dumb pleasures - but when you aim high and fall short, the result is a mess. Or, in this case, a shame, since so many good artists give of their sweat and toil. First, we have Danny Boyle ("28 Days Later"), the director, usually so deft, who can do nothing with the story but light it dramatically and hope for the best; then, there's Michael Fassbender ("Frank"), great as always, who quickly makes you forget that he looks and sounds nothing like Jobs; Kate Winslet ("The Reader") plays Joanna Hoffman, Jobs' loyal assistant, the only person capable of standing up to the mercurial founder of Apple, and she is quite fine, too; Jeff Daniels ("The Newsroom") is here, as well, as John Sculley, the "man who fired Steve Jobs," and holds his own. There's talent to spare, but it doesn't help the script feel any less schematic.The three sections each focus on a different product launch, first in 1984, then 1988, and finally in 1998: the original Macintosh; Steve Jobs' post-Apple venture, the NeXT cube; and his triumphant return with the blue and white iMac. If you know nothing about the man's life and accomplishments (where have you been the last 40 years?), I recommend Walter Isaacson's excellent biography, the likewise eponymous�"Steve Jobs," on which Boyle's and Sorkin's film is ostensibly based.�The idea of comparing launches makes sense, initially, since Jobs was a master showman, known for putting together impressive introductions to new products. However, what sounds good as an idea doesn't work in practice, since Sorkin populates�each event with the exact same group of people revolving around Jobs, hoping to reveal truths through their changing interactions over time, straining credulity with clunky coincidence. Worse, he pares down Jobs' personal life to a single relationship, that with his daughter, Lisa, whom he refused to acknowledge as his for many years. That story is worth telling, but it can hardly be the only point of entry into the man's mind.I think this may be the worst thing I have ever seen written by Sorkin. Forced, packed with artifice,�with the engineering more visible than the design, the film is more PC than Mac. We feel like we're being lectured to, rather than being shepherded towards something new and fresh. I didn't like Alex Gibney's documentary about Jobs, released earlier this year, but by comparison it looks like the far superior film.

As a techie I've always suffered from the inability to explain to my non-tech friends what is that exactly that I do for a living. It'd be cool to be able to share at least a tiny part of the world (you can call it bubble) I'm in, because it's an interesting world, competitive, elitist, subdued and often unintentionally funny. I had high hopes for this movie because I thought it will convey or even try to convey parts of that Silicon Valley vibe to people who aren't in it. But it didn't happen at all. It's really hardly believable, and at times reminded me of Interstellar. Change 'Lisa' to 'Murph', dress Michael Fassbender in a space suit, make him obsess over space rather than computers -- and you get 'Interstellar'. The dynamics between characters are so bland that they would really fit anywhere (like 'Interstellar'). So yeah, certainly better than the other 'Steve Jobs', but worse than 'Social Network' and completely unrepresentative of the real IT thing going on in here. Of course, dialogs by Sorkin and acting by Fassbender & Kate Winslet are brilliant, as always, but still.

Pleasantly surprised; the heart and depth portrayed in this 3-act film moved me in unexpected ways. At the beginning the final product seems dubious and uncertain, but once the pace starts to pick up you are in for a wild ride. The performances are outstanding, specially from Fassbender and Winslet, the direction is assured and energetic, the dialogue sharp and elegant. Not what I expected, but great all the same.

Though the film could have benefited by being a little longer, due to a few elements feeling underdeveloped, Steve Jobs is nonetheless an intoxicating movie. The performances are spot on, the dialogue is as snappy as any Aaron Sorkin movie I've seen, the structure keeps the pace going, and Danny Boyle gives the film an energy that compliments Sorkin's writing perfectly. All in all, even if just judging on individual scenes alone, Steve Jobs has some of the best moments in any film I've seen this year. And as a whole, it's almost as good as its excellent individual parts.

I was absolutely blown away by this film. It treats Jobs as he really was: a real man. He's heavily flawed, to the point of arguably being a bad person, but he's magnetic to watch (largely in part to the excellent Sorkin screenplay and performance by Fassbender). "Steve Jobs" is a win in every way.

Solid film here about three major events in Steve Job's life. The film itself centers around Apple co-founder Steve Jobs (Michael Fassbender). The movie is shot following Jobs around before the three main events: the unveiling of the Mac in 1984, the NEXT in 1988 and the iMac in 1998. The film doesn't have any action per se, but is entirely driven by dialogue. It sounds like it could be slow and it actually is a bit slow, but the characters make it very interesting. Fassbender obviously doesn't look like Steve Jobs, but his performance is excellent. He portrays the right amount of craziness, egotistical mannerisms that made Jobs such an asshole to everyone, but it shows that he had a different side to him at times. The film also stars Kate Winslet as Jobs marketing advisor Joanna Hoffman, Seth Rogen as Co-Founder of Apple Steve Wozniak, Jeff Daniels as Apple CEO John Sculley and Michael Stuhlbarg as Andy Hertzfeld engineer and friend to Jobs. The movie is slow paced, but I enjoyed it and felt like it had a good pace despite only relying on dialogue and character interactions. A truly magnificent portrayal of Steve Jobs by Michael Fassbender gives viewers the in depth look into the perfectionist that was Jobs. If this at all interests you I would highly recommend giving this one a look!

Granted, biopics are really tricky to pull off without the likes of Meryl Streep or Daniel Day Lewis. And, of course, there's usually criticism from those who either love or loathe the main character (for the latter see CBS's reaction to Robert Redford's 'love letter' to Dan Rather). But without pardon, "Steve Jobs", the Danny Boyle/Aaron Sorkin collaboration, so missed the mark that it gives credence to the venomous widow as well as to the former partners at Apple, over the depiction. Neither script nor direction were nearly sophisticated and nuanced enough to use the considerable skills of a terrific cast to make even a decent film. As good as he is an actor, Fassbender was miscast in the title role. Meanwhile, judging by the repetitive use of the same locations, the budget lent to this flawed endeavor was hardly 'Jobsian' either. One might consider this a 'Next' production, rather than a 'Mac' one.  Not surprisingly, given the fanaticism for anything Mac, in limited release, this film actually set per theater attendance records. The early adapters were treated with a Steve Jobs, as shallow as one might expect from an after school special. Even children's programmers wouldn't last more than a season airing a film that wavered almost deliberately between 'boringness and the unpleasant'; allowing virtually no insight on genius nor the excitement of invention that we all witnessed live (assuming you have not been in a coma since 1984). A dour tone was displayed immediately following a delightful :30 bit of archival footage, neatly placed at the front end of the film. That this was the film's highlight remains stunning. Notably embarrassing was the portrayal of the famous Macintosh launch, in which the on screen theater crowd was swept up in frenzied anticipation, including them performing the timelessly nerdy 'wave'. In sharp contrast, by the time the preview ticket-buying crowd was meant to enjoy the historic announcement, the air in the real theater had long since been completely sucked from the room. Viewers sat flabbergasted by the utter insignificance of this portrait. I noticed many heads looking around to see if they were missing something ( the universal sign of a film's failure to suspend audience disbelief - in other words, their not buying in.) I recognized this familiar vacuum and disillusionment during a showing of the insulting Jimi Hendrix biopic released last year (but, at least Andre3000 was believable in the title role of that turd). With all good intention, I desperately wanted to love this movie, as I admired so much its subject. Is true genius really that difficult to recreate in narrative form? Just maybe my view and these harsh words come from a deep disappointment that often accompanies unreasonable and then dashed expectations. But this sad entry still finds me kicking myself for wasting precious time, probably better spent watching Fox's version of our ill functioning Congress, Trump "reality TV', Putin's Middle East folly and the ever present kicks to the groin of Barack and Hillary. Appendix:In hindsight, my eagerness should have been tempered, having read 18 months earlier, that fine filmmaker, David Fincher, originally tapped for this project, and a well know fan of the brilliant Mr. Jobs, left 'the scene' before the crime was perpetrated.
this movie is not for everyone. I've seen worse. felt a bit like amateur hour.

Fassbender channels Jobs and the emotions that he displays is one of his better performances.

God I miss Steve Jobs. Best film of the year so far in terms of all the elements it takes to make an excellent celluloid experience. You can't have a work of cinematic art without superb writing (Aaron Sorkin), impeccable direction (Danny Boyle), Oscar worthy acting performances (primarily Michael Fassbender & Kate Winslet as well as several others in the cast), editing & cinematography to keep the audience engaged throughout and a score to enhance the overall viewing experience. The behind the scenes glimpses into the creator of the concept of the 'reality distortion field' that was Steve Jobs shows a troubled genius destined for greatness.

Well acted and strongly written character piece. Fassbender looks so much like Jobs and turns in a terrific performance, one of his best. Jeff Daniels is also excellent in this... Kate Winslet is a bit off putting in her role, but the supporting players are good. Story is focused on a few key moments of Job's life but the main concept seems to be that he is a real jerk.. watching the film sure makes you want to never buy an apple product again... but it is a very good movie.
Sorkin and Boyle make beautiful music together. Not as bold as Social Network, and yet still one of this years best movies. Fassbender is on fire.

This was a fantastic movie. If you see it, don't go in expecting a biographical movie about Steve Jobs, because that's not what this movie is. This movie focuses on major characters and conflicts in Steve Jobs' life during three major points in his career.

Director Danny Boyle and Michael Fassbender as Steve Jobs magnificently capture a man who was obsessed with detail and control but struggled throughout his life to manage the messiness of human relationships. I think Boyle struggles to make the film something more than just a biopic, but Fassbender and Kate Winslet are a superb acting team that enlighten a film that could simply be two hours of waiting around for a guy to walk on a stage.

The final few minutes seem like a cop out . . . so much of the film portrays Jobs as a brilliant manipulator, that to give the audience a measure of forced sympathy for the man, undermines much of the well executed cynicism. Still, it's completely engaging and this is certainly some of Fassbender's best work.
I thought the movie was awful
Well acted and reasonably entertaining, but isn't as inspired as its cast and crew of heavy hitters would suggest.
Suspenseful, well done, interesting character story. Fassbender was fantastic as was Kate Winslet and Seth Rogan. Sorkin and Daniels continue to work together so well!
The acting in this movie is outstanding. This is a well-crafted movie worthy of Oscar consideration

It's hard to believe that this film is over 2 hours long; it seamlessly blends together three pivotal moments of technological advancement without effort. Sorkin's three-act structure is daring but not completely successful: it's stagey and a bit static, and Fassbender is the slightly too-cold center of a stellar cast. Strange biopic. It more or less covers just a few hours of his life, though there are a few satisfying flashbacks that give glimpses into what made Steve Jobs who he was. Great dialogue, as I expected, good tension, and surprisingly engaging given the lack of plot of real, external conflicts.

Steve Jobs is written by Aaron Sorkin and directed by Danny Boyle. Itstars Micheal Fassbender, Kate Winslet, Seth Rogen, Jeff Daniels, andMichael Stuhlbarg.Set backstage at three iconic product launches and ending in 1998 withthe unveiling of the iMac, Steve Jobs takes us behind the scenes of thedigital revolution to paint a portrait of the man, his estranged familyand staff at its epicenter.I honestly can't start this review without saying this easily ties withmy favorite movie of the year, The Gift, for quite a few reasons. Truthbe told this movie has everything needed to build a classic and uses itremarkably.Writer Aaron Sorkin has quite a few gems in his filmography whichinclude Money Ball, Social Network and A Few Good Men. He is asversatile as he is brutal in honesty. He works wonders in this movierevealing the man behind the machine rather than the machine behind theman. Without any scenes of failure or success, Sorkin forces hisaudience to understand the complex and often times revolting centralCharacter. With extremely well written confrontations between Jobs andWozniak or Jobs and his Daughter or even Jobs and his Boss, Sorkinrelentlessly demonstrates the true nature behind the tech giant. Thoughthis movie's central family tension and the Job vs. Apple drama areenthralling, Sorkin injects just enough dry and black comedy to keepthe movie from becoming an influential figure's shaming. With thatbeing said Sorkin also understands that the enormous ego of Steve Jobshad to be exposed as a vice and plays on that brutal fact perfectly.With 4 dimensional characters, great central dramas and pitch perfectcomedy, this might actually be his best work yet.Accompanying the stellar writing was Danny Boyle's beautiful direction.Through seemingly unending shots and aggressive movements the audiencegenuinely feels like their in Job's presence which can be very hard tosit through at times but is ultimately rewarding experience. Withvisible passion from Boyle, this is one powerful ride.To my common readers I mentioned a few weeks back that Black Mass hadthe greatest ensemble cast of the year, I was wrong. This movies castnever really stops acting to the point of absolute realism. To startKate Winslet portrayal of real life Johanna Hoffman was as beautiful asit was naive. She brought the character alive in full force and trulydemonstrated she is one of the best actresses working. I smell anomination coming her way. I had referenced Jeff Daniel's acting lastweek in The Martian, well he completely out did himself. He was tenderat times and shark-like in others. He drew the line betweenintelligence and decency and walks this tight rope carefully. Five yearold Mekenzie Moss also offers an absolutely astounding performance,uttering few but heart wrenching words. Michael Stuhlbarg works wonderas well on a albeit smaller degree. Now onto the two heavy hitters. A surprise to me and my theater alike,Seth Rogan gives the single best dramatic performance of his career. AsSteve Wozniak, the literal opposite of Jobs, Rogan played the role withelegance and brilliance and I wouldn't even mind the Benicio snub ifRogen won the statue. The role demanded a sweet, naive, caring andultimately explosive performance and Rogan more than delivered makingthe scenes of abrasion between him and Fassbender iconic. I have been holding off that name for the entire review because MichealFassbender is the only thing keeping this movie from failing. He dawnsthe character in such a way, I can only compare it to Jake Gyllenhaalfrom Night Crawler and even then I don't think I could fully describeit. Filled to the brim with nuance Fassbender offers a cold,intelligent, manipulative, calculating, and over all disturbinglyrealistic portrayal of Steve Jobs. I really can't envision a bettercast lead than him. As calm as he is diabolical, Fassbender plays thisegotistical narcissist with such precision its close to horrifying towatch. Though calm through most of the movie Fassbender understandswhen to unleash the monster which lays in Jobs and is absolutelyvolcanic while doing so. Under all the deception, tyranny, andtechnological brilliance lays a purely adroit and masterful performance.Though Johnny Depp in Black Mass was great and Ian McClellan in Mr.Holmes was grand, neither of them embodied their characters much likeMicheal Fassbender and it would be a shame and a disservice to cinemaif he didn't with Best Actor. He has proved he is one of the bestactors of the generation.Steve Jobs was a privilege to see on the big screen and is so far tiedwith The Gift as my number one movie of the year. Boyle's unconventional biopic feeds off Aaron Sorkin's evocative structure to tackle the life of an uncompromising and disturbed visionary. In Steve Jobs there is an unflinching desire to portray the man and yet there is this idea that we we can't get to the depth of his complexity despite being told how layered he is. The filmmakers' kinetic, fast-paced and often time voracious inclinations service the pace but hardly the heart and what made Jobs such a seminal figure of our time. There are undeniable touches of greatness in Steve Jobs, mainly with regards to visual cues and Sorkin ever-so eargasmic banter. After all we are talking about filmmakers at the top of their game. The emphasis in style, however, proved to be a disservice to the cinematic language that could have been or, alternatively, that was meant to be. Perhaps that is why the end product, which runs out of ideas pretty quickly, seems meandering and lacking a clear goal whether that is emotional existentialist or even technological. The punchlines land, one after the other, but the essence doesn't.

Steve Jobs is Aaron Sorkin gone wrong. It's a fast-paced mess of edgy dialog that barely goes under the surface, tells a story that's barely interesting (to me, anyway), and ends up in a place that finally DOES go somewhere, but in a forced way that comes way too late. I came close to leaving the theater a couple of times because I was simply bored. In fact, a slower-paced but deeper and more intriguing screenplay would have held be firmly in my seat. I found myself not giving a whit about Steve Jobs or the people around him, due to how little the movie goes beneath the surface. It tries to, but ends up focusing on the wrong things. I get why Sorkin chose to do it this way, but it was a mistake. In my opinion Steve Jobs didn't do anything significant as a human, aside from help shape some products that a lot of us like, along with some fantastic marketing...which is part of the problem with the movie. It underlines that fact, and it could have done so in a way that's more gripping and fascinating, but instead has a bunch of characters that are simply walking around and talking without much overall movement (again, until the very end). The biography of Steve Jobs is far more interesting, telling, and scintillating that this sleep-inducing effort. I felt no admiration for Jobs after seeing this flick, nor did I feel any supreme disdain, aside from him being a robotic, soulless man who helped market things well. There are some moments of interest and some great acting, but there's no real movie to found here.

Aaron Sorkin's typically razor-ship insights and unique tongue-twisting but deeply intellectual and emotive dialogue get their best showcase yet under the masterfully symphonic direction of Danny Boyle and a totally on-form cast. Shot in three different film formats with an inspired framing device during peak periods of Apple and NEXT's product launches, the film magnifies the human drama of Jobs both in personal and professional ways and, despite his many real-life detractors, paints him with more humanity than he's been given in prior treatments. The film propulsively moves with the breakneck speed of the best action thriller without any explosions or set pieces. The best playwrights have said "character is action" and Sorkin deftly manuevers statistics, backstories, family drama and the relentlessness of the pursuit of perfection as themes spun into what amounts as an engineering feat of its own merits. Although it is a meant to be a portrait of a great, misanthropic and by mainstream understanding deeply reviled man, the men who put their blood, sweat and tears into this project ought to be revered generations from now for this once-in-a-blue-moon accomplishment.

Brilliantly done. Aaron Sorkin (as always) worked his magic, and the result is a wonderfully told story. It has the feel of a beautifully cinematic Stage play, and in shot wonderfully. Fictional or not, Sorkin gets right to the core of Jobs as a character-creating a wonderfully complex, torn, human person-which in the end, left me moved.

Most of the movie is devoted to showing us that Steve Jobs was an irascible, unpleasant character and a bad parent rather than on what made him a tech god. As such, while the movie boasts fine performances and typically sharp Sorkin dialogue, it feels like it doesn't fully capture who Jobs was.

While Steve Jobs feels like an already explored territory, with the long lines and satirical tone of an Aaron Sorkin dialogue, delivered in a very fast manner to create enough tension to make it as engaging as possible. You get the feeling from beginning to end that there's a trial to mimic The Social Network in terms of humanizing a tech legend and exposing his flaws on a different side of his life, but even if Aaron Sorkin is the same writer of both screenplays, Danny Boyle's vision is massively different from that of Fincher's, which resulted in a somehow fresh feeling in the delivery of events, pace and general atmosphere. Michael Fassbender is by far the best thing about Steve Jobs, he delivers another brilliant performance as usual and cements his place as one of best and most serious actors alive. Jobs has an all star supporting cast, though only a few of them shine in relatively new roles to their careers (Seth Rogen, Michael Stuhlberg), others fall desperately in between the unorthodox setting in the movie's events, the ,sometimes, tremendously forced dialogue, and ultimately fail in even giving an average performance (Kate Winslet, Kathrine Waterston, Jeff Daniels). All in all, even though the material has been used before, and Sorkin has lost his touch to an extent, Steve Jobs still feels like an original biopic, all thanks to a visionary director and a simple yet mesmerizing performance by its lead.
